QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney‐General and the Minister for Justice. I remind the minister that during the last election cam paign you announced, and now your government proposes, a cut of $1½ million from the budget of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and to do so by transferring hearings from the commission to the Human Rights Division of the Federal Court. Since you were so deeply involved in the decision and since you now represent the Attorney, what would it therefore cost the Human Rights Division to hold these hearings?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator Bolkus, for that question. I do not have a precise figure in mind as to what it would cost them to hold those hearings. But let us be clear about this: has it possibly dawned on you yet why the decision making has to be shifted from the human rights commission? If you had a clue as to that, you would understand that, quite against advice from the other side of the chamber as it then was, from the opposition at the time, you took the view that you could proceed to make the human rights commission into a court without it being a court. You let it operate under that misunderstanding for quite a considerable period.

ANSWER.PARA: This was not an isolated example. There are plenty of other examples of where your then government was warned as to the unconstitutionality of proposals that it sought to get through this parliament and, sadly, did get through, one way or another. You later found, as a consequence of the Brandy decision, that it was not possible to do that which you had, I believe, come into this chamber when you were then representing the Attorney and said was possible.

Do I gather from the blank look on your face that you do understand that much—that your then government got it wrong? You tried to get the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to do something for which there was no constitutional backing to allow you to do. So that had to fall apart. You were warned at the time by quite prominent people outside the parliament that this was a hazardous path for you to take. You were warned it was a hazardous path both constitutionally and in light of the people who would suffer if you got it wrong—that is, the people who need the protection of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. You were prepared to play a card game with their opportunities, their future and the determinations that were going to be made.

You later found, as I have indicated, that you were wrong and that had to be changed. Come the election, you were one of the people, with other members on what was then this side, when you were formerly the government—now the defeated and rejected government, the government which the people of Australia don't want—who called on us to say what we would do to resolve that matter. I understand that you were one of the people—I could be misinformed; I would be happy for you to tell me if this is the case—running around the country saying, `I'll tell you what the coalition are going to do. They're going to gut the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. They don't care about human rights.'

It was a great shame for you to have to realise that our policy said that we did care about human rights—that has always been our position—and the manner in which we would resolve the dilemma created by your government's ineptitude was to shift not only the decision making to the Federal Court and create a separate division for those matters, but the hearings as well.

Why do you think we did that? We did that because there is no point in wasting the time and money of litigants. These people are not necessarily very wealthy people, who need the benefit of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. There is no point in having two hearings. So we said we would simplify this process and we would have the hearings in a separate division of the Federal Court and they will make the determinations.

We made some assessments. Admittedly, from opposition, you don't have it down to the last cent. But we believed it was a pretty close and reasonable assessment—or we did at the time believe that. If we have had subsequent advice on that matter, I am not aware of it. Nonetheless, we think that is a very sensible way to protect the rights of Australians who want to take the opportunities and advantages offered to them or use the protection of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question. That answer is something that is pretty well known to anyone who has been involved in the discussion here. But what we are about is getting the detail. Detail is important for the continued operation of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. Minister, you are the one who proposed the transfer. You are the one who identified the cuts. Given that the proper estimate as supplied by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission of the cost of the hearing function is only $720,000 a year, what other functions does the government expect HREOC to cut in order to make that saving of over twice that amount—that saving of $1½ million? Can you guarantee that HREOC will not be gutted in terms of its functions because of the loose approach that you took to funding and resourcing this area, and the decision making you took?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say a couple of things with respect to that. From my experience in opposition, which was extensive, I can advise you that you will soon understand that the reason you will not have some information is we will not give it to you if we do not want to. Within the bounds of propriety we will be more responsible to parliament than you were.

ANSWER.PARA: We have to work on guesstimates because you would not open all the books. You would not open them before the election campaign so that the community, Australia at large, could see the $8 billion black hole. So you have never wanted to open up the books at all—never at all!

Let me tell you this: sadly, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission—any area of government—will have to bear the burden of your mismanagement. So perhaps you would like to tell them why you have left them in the position of cuts having to be made. (Time expired)

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Environment: Great Australian Bight Marine Park

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment. Minister, do you support the actions taken by the South Australian government to declare South Australia's first marine park over part of the Great Australian Bight? What will you as Minister for the Environment and the government be doing to address the many problems that face our coastal zone, particularly that of coastal pollution?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Calvert for his question. Senator Calvert has taken a great interest in the marine environment. I welcome the opportunity to indicate the government's support for the South Australian decision to proceed with the declaration of a large, multiple‐use marine park in the Great Australian Bight to protect the breeding grounds of the southern right whale and the endangered Australian sea lion—a further sign of an enlightened Liberal government, I might say, in South Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: In fact, only last weekend I had the opportunity at a conference arranged by the South Australian Conservation Council to examine the issues associated with the development of a comprehensive network of marine protected areas. At that conference I was able to recommit this government to the development of a comprehensive oceans policy—something that Labor was never either able or willing to do—and that policy will examine the issues confronting Australia since the declaration last year of the 200 nautical mile exclusive economic zone.

BREAK.PARA: I believe that the Commonwealth should take appropriate action to help support marine environments and I have asked my department to advise me on how the Commonwealth can best support the South Australian initiative. Multiple‐use marine protected areas are an important tool in the management of our valuable marine bio‐diversity.

Currently, Mr President, you might be interested to know that about 5.2 per cent of Australia's marine areas are in protected areas. This is not as good a performance as first appears because 74 per cent of that is taken up with the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thanks to us.

—That means, Senator Cook, that much still needs to be done in temperate waters. The State of the Marine Environment Report released in 1995 demonstrates that estuaries and coastal waters in the developed parts of Australia are suffering moderate to serious problems. These problems are caused by pollution from elevated levels of nutrients arising from poor inland water quality and land management, stormwater run‐off from urban areas, sewage and industrial discharges. These problems are compounded by a loss of habitat, dredging, beach and dune erosion, overdevelopment, loss of amenity and poor long‐term planning.

BREAK.PARA: Sewage and stormwater run‐off are the major sources of nutrients in urban areas. Most of Australia's sewerage is only treated to a secondary stage and remains high in nutrients. Unfortunately, each year about 10,000 tonnes of phosphorous and 100,000 tonnes of nitrogen are discharged through sewage.

Australia's unique temperate seagrasses appear to be under particular threat. Increased sedimentation and nutrients from catchment have been linked with massive dieback of seagrasses in many parts. New South Wales has lost about a half of the seagrasses in its estuaries while, in Victoria, about 85 per cent of the total biomass of seagrasses has been lost in Westernport Bay.

The costs to remedy this deficiency of the past are, of course, enormous. Engineering to reduce algal growth in Cockburn Sound would cost $170 million; the Peel Harvey estuary in Western Australia $50 million; and the Tuggerah Lakes in New South Wales $12 million.

The answer is the new government's $100 million coasts and clean seas initiative which will provide the funding base to tackle these problems of coastal and marine pollution, particularly pollution caused by sewerage and stormwater in the most densely populated areas of Australia.

How could we imagine that, facing that problem, the opposite parties in this place, the Australian Labor Party, the Australian Democrats and the Greens (WA), would block the attempt by this government to remedy this major deficiency, this major problem that needs to be overcome. And, for that, they should hang their heads in shame. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney‐General and the Minister for Justice. Minister, in keeping your campaign promise to achieve `better cost recovery' by the Insolvency and Trustee Service of Australia, it was estimated you would raise $15 million over three years. Given that ITSA recovers its costs from the estates of bankrupts, will not any increase in cost recovery be at the expense of the creditors, the innocent parties in insolvency cases?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Chris Evans for his question. I will take this opportunity to advise you, because you may not have been at the relevant committee hearings, and other senators who may be interested that ITSA circulated amongst its staff—I think sometime last year, if not the year before, but it certainly was not this year—a briefing note indicating that they should not resolve too many bankruptcies too soon because if they did it would get less money from the finance department.

ANSWER.PARA: In effect, the note said, `Look guys, why don't you slow down on the job. You're actually doing too good a job. You're actually resolving too many of these at any one time, in any one period. If you keep solving them at this rate, the pile of unsolved ones will go down—ipso facto we will get less money. Why don't you concentrate on something else. Why don't you concentrate on the development of government policy and how we will implement it.'

If that does not tell you that something was seriously wrong in ITSA in terms of management and the allocation of its time, I do not know what does. ITSA should have been working as one of the most efficient bodies to deliver the best service possible to the innocent parties—and you are right—creditors and anybody involved. They should have been able to benchmark themselves and set up as the standard to follow. They were either unable or, as the particular memo I am referring to indicates to me, unwilling to do so.

At the estimates committee the relevant officer was queried about this memo and there was some embarrassment about this on his part. There was some embarrassment that a private ITSA memo had been released and the public at large could see what was going on. The advice he gave the committee was that the interpretation I have just given you of that memo was somewhat harsh.

He would have us believe that he was simply concerned to see that ITSA officials spent the appropriate amount of time on each bankruptcy and that they should not solve them too quickly because they might miss something. He said that they should spend a lot more time on every one so that they could be 100 per cent sure that every one was done 100 per cent correctly. He said that it was wrong to read the memo as, `This will be bad for us in relation to our staffing level negotiations with the Department of Finance.'

I will produce the memo and leave it to senators opposite and those on this side and members of the public to judge. I indicate to you that I took one look at that and said that something was wrong. These people have an opportunity to set a standard or to demonstrate quite clearly that it is possible for public sector people to do a top class, world class job which the private sector could use as a benchmark. I have indicated to you—and I think if you speak to anybody who has had some experience with ITSA they will agree—that they failed to do that. On that basis, there needed to be some changes. A little bit of a brush with reality and some market prices just might have done it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I was interested in the minister's comments about what somebody else had to say, but the real question was: why is it that small businesses are being made to suffer, as a result of the government's decision, because the costs will be at their expense?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the point you need to understand is where bankruptcies come from. It is true that some of it is a result of mismanagement. There is no doubt about that. You cannot say that a business goes bankrupt without any fault on its own part. You must also understand that under your government the level of bankruptcies was outrageously high. Your failure to attend to the economy and the trouble with interest rates—one could go on at length—have ensured that a very large number of people went bankrupt.

ANSWER.PARA: The point I have simply put to you is: what is in the interests of the innocent parties, the creditors, and, for that matter, the people going bankrupt? It is that their estate is handled as efficiently, as quickly and as sensibly as possible. We had the head of the show or the senior officer writing to the junior staff saying, `Don't do too much of this too quickly because it will be a bit difficult when we have to negotiate our agreement with finance and we will get fewer staff.' If you think that that means they were doing the best job possible by the creditors, you shop at a different supermarket to me, Sport.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. Has the Labor opposition offered bipartisan support to the coalition government's strategy to bring the budget into surplus? Can the minister explain the benefits to the Australian people that would flow from a bipartisan approach?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Ellison for that very important question because it really goes to the heart of whether the Labor Party has learnt the lessons of its defeat at the last election. It also goes right to the heart of whether Labor has learnt to act responsibly in the interests of the Australian people. As to whether there may be bipartisan support, I can only say to Senator Ellison that the situation is that the opposition seems to be hopelessly divided on that. You only have to look at examples over the last few days in this chamber and outside to see that.

ANSWER.PARA: Only last Saturday at the ALP's Victorian state conference, the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley, said that this $8 billion suggestion is a deceit, plain and simple, a deceit. He said further that this $8 billion black hole is a chimera put up for political purposes—a con job by Mr Costello. That was preceded a couple of days earlier, as I reminded the Senate yesterday, by that incredible matter of public importance debate put up by Senator Sherry where he said that the task of bringing the budget into underlying surplus was an ideological pursuit. Those two do not sound too encouraging to me, Senator Ellison.

I draw some encouragement from the statement in the other place last week by the shadow Treasurer, Mr Gareth Evans, who first of all acknowledged that there was an underlying deficit of around $8 billion. He actually put it at $7.6 billion, but that is near enough I would think by Labor's standards. Encouragingly, he also appeared to agree with the government on the importance of bringing the budget back into surplus. Mr Evans said in the House last week—and I quote this for the benefit of members opposite and their leader, Mr Beazley:
Of course the opposition accepts—as it did in government—that it is very desirable, other things being equal, for there to be a return to underlying fiscal balance as soon as possible.

I hope that that does mean that we can expect some bipartisan support in our efforts to solve the fundamental fiscal problems facing this nation. The first thing, obviously, that has to happen is for the Leader of the Opposition, his deputy leader and the Minister for Finance to get down and have a little quiet talk amongst themselves and sort out which way they want to go and what they really think about the question of the budget deficit and the need to bring it back into balance. Then, hopefully, they will come forward to this place and to the Australian people with some semblance of good order, rationality and bipartisanship in tackling the fundamental problems that this government has been elected to correct in the interests not only of the Australian people but of the whole Australian nation.

ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

—Here is more of Senator Vanstone's understanding of ministerial accountability; she indicated to the Senate earlier on that she will give an answer only if she wants to. I ask the minister: if she treats a Queensland coalition colleague the way she has treated Mr Quinn, with such utter contempt, what hope do students and young people in Queensland have that their needs for more university places will be listened to?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry, Senator; you seem to misunderstand. I am seeing Mr Quinn before I catch up with a number of other state ministers and with a number of providers who are interested in what the government's policies are going to mean for them. He is getting an appointment just as everyone else is. I do not believe he has been treated with contempt at all. We are having our meeting. If his plane rolls up on time, the meeting will go ahead today. I look forward to it.

—My question is to the minister representing the Treasurer. Minister, your government has made the repeated claim that the sale of Telstra will add to national savings and improve the economy. Are you aware of savings expert Dr Vince FitzGerald's assessment that the sale of Telstra will not add to national savings, because the fall in debt is cancelled out by the fall in assets? Do you agree with the analysis by Access Economics that the privatisation of Telstra will have no significant benefit for the macro‐economy? And do you agree with Professor Bob Walker that privatisations always result in a sale price less than the value of keeping the asset in public hands? Minister, there is no economic justification, is there, for the sale of any part of Telstra?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —I can only say, through you, Mr President, to Senator Kernot that she obviously has never heard of the words `efficiency', `competition' and `effectiveness', because the sale of one‐third of Telstra will bring enormous benefits.
—To whom?

—To every Australian, in a variety of ways. Senator Alston has very eloquently outlined many of those benefits in the last days in this sitting. I do not know where you have been, but those benefits that he has outlined are enormous.

ANSWER.PARA: They include major economic benefits because they are a major part of the program that this government has to improve efficiency and competitiveness in major Australian infrastructure industries so that we can get on with the job of becoming increasingly internationally competitive and we can remove the roadblocks that the former government, very frequently with, I have to say regrettably to Senator Kernot, the support of the Australian Democrats, put in the way of efficiency and international competitiveness for this nation.

That is the reason why we have finished up with a black hole in the budget of $8 billion. That is why we have finished up with interest rates amongst the highest in the Western world. That is why when Labor lost office three-quarters of a million Australians were still unemployed despite 18 quarters of economic growth. That is why no major reforms at all had been undertaken on an ongoing basis throughout the economy to get the basic structure of the economy sufficiently internationally competitive and efficient to produce great benefits, to release opportunities and to allow Australians to capitalise on the great resources, opportunities, talents and skills we have as a people and as a nation.

If Senator Kernot does not understand, first of all, that the telecommunications industry is a fundamental part of that and, secondly, that having a private ownership interest in Telstra—by `private ownership' we mean ownership by all Australians—

TALK.START.PARA: —We already own it!
—Order!

—I do not know who you think is going to own this one-third but they are overwhelmingly going to be Australians. If you cannot understand the benefits that all of that produces, I suggest you go back to the drawing board and have another look.

—Minister, in your justification for this bill I did not hear a word about national savings or budget bottom lines. Yesterday we had the example of the increase in profitability of 65 per cent over the next three years. Can't you see that there is the possibility that selling Telstra will damage the budget? Why are you rejecting criteria such as adding to national savings, which were really important to you when you were in opposition? It is true, isn't it, that we already own Telstra and there is no future in the argument that Australians can buy it? Finally, are you putting the argument of benefits to business ahead of your concerns for the rest of Australians in their access to residential and other telephone services in remote and rural areas?

—So far as the latter part of Senator Kernot's supplementary question is concerned, all of those situations are totally protected in the legislation before the parliament. So you are setting up an enormous straw man. You are creating fears in large sections of the community which are absolutely and totally unfounded. So far as the other part of your supplementary question is concerned, the fundamental reason—
—National savings.

—No. The fundamental reason for the partial privatisation of Telstra is to make Telstra more efficient and competitive. That is the base reason. There are other important spin‐off economic reasons, but the basic purpose for the partial privatisation of Telstra is to improve its competitive position and its efficiency because it is such a fundamental part of the Australian infrastructure. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, of Australians in employment in this country at the moment, how many are full time and how many are part time? Do you believe that the ratio between full time and part time is satisfactory? If not, why not? What ratio of full-time to part-time employment do you favour by the end of the financial year 1997?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the senator for her question. It gives me the opportunity to highlight one of the very key differences between my government and what was her government when she presumably supported the Labor Party when they were on this side before they were so comprehensively rejected.

ANSWER.PARA: As for the exact numbers, there is a parliamentary library. I can give you the numbers to the research service. If you want to get that sort of information looked up, I suggest that you do. I do not carry the exact numbers around in my head. I have no intention of trying to remember the monthly figures month by month down to the last 10, 100 or whatever.
But let me get to the key difference between your party and mine. You asked me what proportion of full-time and part-time work I favoured. I favour whatever proportion the community wants.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—Oh, it is a surprise to you. You social engineers over there like to organise what people would like. Do you know what my ideal is? My ideal with respect to workplace arrangements is that people can choose what they want. I would like to see a situation where, if someone wanted to do part-time work for whatever reason—Senator, did you want the answer to this question or are you engaging in another conversation? Sorry; did you want the rest of this answer?
—It wasn't her question anyway.
—It was not your question anyway.

BREAK.PARA: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Vanstone has the call.

—I would like to see people who want to work part time getting the opportunity to do that. But I tell you what I would also like to see: people who wanted a real job being able to get it. The mix between those two is up to individuals to choose.

BREAK.PARA: You might think it is appropriate that there are more women in full-time employment; you might think it is appropriate that more are in part-time employment. I think it is appropriate that there are opportunities in the workplace for people to do what they want to do—not what the government engineers them into doing. I am not going to go into Civic and make some plan with the department as to how we can make sure the ratio comes to this or the ratio comes to that. This is a ludicrous question.

Since the important thing on this side of the chamber is to give people a real choice, and that means that the jobs have to be there, let me run through a few of the things that we want to do in order to ensure that those real job opportunities are there. We intend to loosen up the industrial relations system to make it more flexible. We intend to get rid of your former government's unfair unfair dismissal law and to replace it with a fair one. We will make some tax simplification changes that will be of assistance to small business.

We will cut the red tape that, despite all the pontificating from colleagues around here, grew and grew under your government. We have set up a task force and its charter is to come up with a reduction in red tape of 50 per cent that can be delivered to small business. When we can make some of these changes—and I look forward to your support on them, Senator—we might see the economy somewhat more buoyant, we might see real jobs and people will make the choice between full-time work and part-time work as they choose.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service. Is the minister aware of the fact that Tasmania is suffering the highest unemployment rate of any state in Australia and that the Public Service cuts will further burden our island state? Is the minister aware that the Public Service cuts are falling as determined by heads of Public Service departments? Is he also aware that there is a trend in these particular cuts for the centralisation of functions from the regions to central offices in various capital cities, apart from our own capital city? Would the Prime Minister examine this issue to see whether it is consistent with the policy of the government and indeed of the Liberal Party in respect of decentralisation in rural development?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President—
—You might like to acknowledge that they have started to sack them in Darwin.

—It is a pity the voters did not go quite as far as they should have in your case, Bob. In answer to Senator Harradine's question, I am not aware of the particular details of the impact of any proposed cuts in relation to Tasmania. But let me say that I hope the residents of Tasmania are aware of why it is that it is necessary for us to impose further stringencies on the Australian economy. We do not do it lightly. We do not do it simply because of some ideological binge.

ANSWER.PARA: The reality is that even prior to the election that lot over there were well and truly embarked on a hidden agenda in terms of Public Service cuts. What you will find at the present time is that Senator Vanstone's department is looking at cuts of just over 1,265. Of those, there will be something in the order of 965 that will be lost as a direct result of decisions previously made by that lot over there. So, in other words, there are already significant cuts in train.

BREAK.PARA: I take your point about the importance of ensuring that people outside the capital cities or the principal towns are not deprived of services. That in many respects is a separate but very important issue. One of the consequences of reductions must be to ensure that at the end of the day you do not impose more pain in one area than in another. To the extent that there are greater claims on departments in rural and remote areas, then obviously you would expect the government to be sensitive to those claims.

I can certainly assure you that if you are asked why it is that we have to endure further pain then you ought to tell them about Beazley's black hole and you ought to tell them about Senator Sherry thinking it is simply an ideological pursuit. The fact is of course that that in itself is the ultimate ideological statement. Really and truly I just hope that over the recess Senator Sherry does a crash course in economics and understands the importance of actually getting the budget back into surplus.

Unless you get the budget back into surplus, you end up having to borrow. The interest charges that are devoted to debt retirement are money that could have been spent elsewhere. It could certainly have been spent in Tasmania and it could certainly be spent ensuring that people get access to the services that they require. So let the blame lie precisely where it falls. We will do the best we can to minimise the damage. But, at the end of the day, I think everyone knows who is responsible for the present processes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure the supplementary question would have been expected, because the minister referred to the fact that certain of these cuts are taking place as a result of decisions by the previous administration. An example is the closure of the tax office in Launceston. Another example is that 90 per cent of the staff of Comcare in Hobart offices are likely to go, with the functions transferred to Victoria. That is the point I am making. In this day and age of technology, is it justified that the heads of Public Service departments should take that action and thus violate, as I understand it, a policy of your government in respect of decentralisation? I am asking you to ask the Prime Minister to investigate those decisions by the heads of Public Service departments to see whether they are consistent with your policy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —I will certainly undertake to consult with the Prime Minister and to obtain further instructions on the extent to which those proposals are compatible with our approach to decentralisation. As you would well appreciate, in this day and age with on-line services it is possible to do a great many things from very remote locations. I can well recall Senator Bob Collins, when asked about where the pay television headquarters ought to be located, said, `You could easily put it on Ayers Rock.' In other words it does not really matter, technically speaking.

ANSWER.PARA: We do not want to go down that path. We certainly want to ensure that we minimise the social dislocation that flows from rationalisations. But, where it is possible to ensure that the decentralisation program benefits people in those rural areas, consistent with the rationalisation program, we are very keen to do that. I will come back to Senator Harradine with further information.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Can you confirm that NETTFORCE has been a highly successful initiative in terms of providing opportunities for traineeships? If this is the case, why is it your intention to close down NETTFORCE?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to your question, Senator, depends on what your definition of successful is. There has been a very genuine effort on the part of the NETTFORCE board, which, as you will know, includes the former Premier of Victoria Joan Kirner, Lindsay Fox, Bill Kelty and a number of other people who have made a very determined and conscientious effort to fulfil the task that they were given. As a consequence of their efforts and those of others, some training companies have been set up to develop programs, traineeships. Some of them have been very substantially more successful than others.
—What were the results?
—That experiment has had its chance to run and we can now see—
—What is the evidence?
—The evidence is the number of traineeships.
—Will you answer the question?

—Senator Crowley, you can get an answer for this—or do you want me to answer all the interjections from everyone else? You make the choice. You ought to bring your colleagues into line here. If you are interested in the answer to your question, which it appears that you are, you might ask your colleagues to button up and stop trying to jump the queue and ask other questions. I will stay focused on you and just give you the answer.

ANSWER.PARA: The performance of the training companies is fairly obvious. Some will obviously survive and flourish; others will disappear because they have not been as successful. I cannot imagine that you, Senator Crowley, would disagree with that. Where a company has been successful and is working well, we would obviously want to use the expertise that has been created and the opportunities that have been generated. Companies that have not been successful can drift into the sunset. This is the business—as you well know; you have had some experience of it—of governments. You try something. When it works you keep it going. If it doesn't, you don't. It is as simple as that. That is the answer with respect to the board and the arrangements, without, for example, looking at what our policies might be.

You might well be aware that we want to modernise the apprenticeship and traineeship scheme, and that will require some different arrangements. It is a sad story for you that you lost government and that we are now going to implement our policies. That means some changes will have to be made. We are not scuttling the traineeships—not at all. We want there to be more opportunities for apprenticeships and traineeships for young Australians. But we are entitled in the development and implementation of our policy to say that there will be other arrangements for promoting these things.

NETTFORCE was suitable at the time for your arrangements. But we have new arrangements which we think will create many more opportunities for young Australians. I think you will see some legislation outlining at least partly the basis of the modernised apprenticeship and traineeship scheme very soon in the other place. You will then be able to see what the benefits will be for young Australians.

The short answer is that NETTFORCE was set up by your government. Those people did some very good work. They were very conscientious; I have no doubt about that. But across party lines there is an agreement that we all have to do everything we can to create real opportunities and provide decent traineeships for young Australians. The sad fact that you need to remember is that your lot lost the election. Our policies are now going to be introduced and the modernised apprenticeship and traineeship scheme is the central plank of the vocational education and training opportunities that we are going to create for young Australians, and we believe that that will require different arrangements. We are working on what those arrangements will be—but we are satisfied that the NETTFORCE board will not be a part of those arrangements.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you referred to your answer as depending on what the definition of success is. Is it not true that NETTFORCE figures show that even in the last nine months traineeship vacancies have trebled on the previous year to 28,931? Did you not say in your letter to Lindsay Fox that NETTFORCE had `contributed to the considerable growth in traineeship numbers which we are now experiencing in 1996'. Why then are you closing it down? What formal evaluation have you had done, particularly by the department—
—The honourable senator's time has expired.
—On a point of order, Mr President: the clock was never set, so the time did not expire. I think there is a difficulty there.
—I think you had finished your question, had you not, Senator Crowley?
—I just want to make clear the last sentence. Why then are you closing it down? What formal evaluation have you done, particularly by the department, and will you publish that evaluation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I will try to spell it out a bit more clearly for you. I want to say two things to you. Let me see if I can get you to understand them, because they are fairly simple. The first thing is that in my original answer to you I acknowledged the good work and dedication of NETTFORCE board members. In your supplementary question you queried why I had said that they had made a significant contribution. It was simply because they had. I would have thought that was obvious from my first answer. You can go back and have a look at it.

ANSWER.PARA: The second point is that you seem to think, Senator, that in order to make a change we have to have an evaluation done and come and ask for your approval.

TALK.START.PARA: —But in your first answer you said you were having one. That was your answer.

—Let me tell you what the evaluation of the community was of your government. It was that you were not doing well enough. You got evaluated. Once every few years we go to the electorate and we ask them what they think—and they thought your time was up. And it is now time for us to introduce our policies. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. In the light of the government's commitment to privatise one‐third of Telstra, can the minister outline what has been the experience for customers as a result of the privatisation of British Telecom?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very grateful to Senator Panizza for asking the questions that the Democrats clearly were not prepared to put on the table. The fact is that, since 1984, in the UK there have been absolutely dramatic improvements in both quality of service and price reductions for consumers of British Telecom. The average British Telecom, or BT, business customer bill has more than halved in real terms. Conceded?
—Yes, but—

—So that is one we will put on the board, thank you. Secondly, the average residential bill over that period has gone down by more than one‐third. So there is two big ticks for you. The cost of telecommunications has also fallen very sharply for smaller residential customers. So the total bill of the typical low user residential customer has fallen by over 20 per cent. Those are enormous gains and improvements for consumers. The reason that they happen is because, without the efficiencies in the system—
—Oh!

—Well, you can roll your ideological eyes as much as you like, Senator Bourne, but the fact is you are simply not in a position to offer those sorts of price reductions if the firm is not operating efficiently. You want to trot out all that bottom‐of‐the‐garden mythology about `we own the company anyway'. Well, the fact is, you do not. You have never had the slightest control over it. You have never in any way been able to influence any of its decisions.
—What?

—Do you know who has? This was Keating's personal fiefdom. Don't you recall? He went along to Frank Blount and said, `I want you to sell off Yellow Pages.' And when Mr Blount said he did not want to do that, Keating decided they would take almost a billion dollars off the bottom line in terms of the dividend payment—not only increases, but early repayments of the loan.
—Public owned companies should not pay dividends to the government?
—Don't have apoplexy, Bob. We need you here.
—A billion dollars a year in dividends?

—Yes, $934 million was the figure last year. It is tragic to think that someone equates a level of profit or even revenue with efficiency. They are utterly unrelated propositions. Telstra's profit actually went up—you should know this, Senator Schacht, when you are not busy running around the countryside. Where did you come, third in the TA stakes? Good effort! If you look at the figures, you will find that operating expenses rose at a higher rate than the profit figures. No wonder they put you together; no-one else would want to sit with you.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that, unless you concentrate on those efficiencies, you will not be able to get those price reductions. That is why, if you look at the experience in BT, they have achieved dramatic improvements. I think it is also very unfortunate that Senator Woodley has not been up here today apologising. I presume he has had a look at section 287 since yesterday and he knows that what is in our bill precisely mirrors the universal service obligation.

All of those schemes and proposals are based on the UK model, where it has worked very efficiently. In fact, we go further than they do in terms of their price caps. We ensure that not only do residential rates come down, but access charges as well. As I hope you know, 70 per cent of the telecommunications bill of residential consumers consists of local call charges and access lines.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was there a regulator involved in any of this?
—In the UK?
—Yes, in the UK.

—Well, of course there is. You ought to know that we have one modelled precisely on it. Theirs is Oftel; ours is Austel. The name gives it away. Ours is based entirely on their model, and they have been massive winners. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister representing the Attorney-General and the Minister for Justice, Senator Vanstone. Minister, will you end the speculation and concern in northern Tasmania about the future of the Family Court in Launceston by giving a commitment now to keep the court open?
—`Yes' will do.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for the answer, Senator. That is a matter I will address to the Attorney. I will come back with an answer for you.

—Will you also ensure that, when you seek your advice from the Attorney‐General, you will take note of what Senator Alston said, your policy commitment and also a commitment by your colleague, Warwick Smith, the new member for Bass, that he would guarantee the future of the court.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have said, I will get an answer for you from the Attorney.

—My question is to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Short. I ask the minister: will the government confirm its intention to consider a levy to finance the buyback of firearms in the community? Secondly, how much money per annum is raised by the existing sales tax on firearms, including accessories and ammunition? Finally, is the government willing to dedicate also this money to the buyback scheme?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Spindler for his question. As he will be aware, the Prime Minister has stressed that removing dangerous firearms from the community is of critical importance to set us in the right direction as a society. As he said in the other place yesterday, as to the question of gun control laws, the government is strongly of the view that we need effective uniform legislation. We need to achieve a total prohibition on the ownership, possession, sale and importation of all automatic and semi-automatic weapons. That will be the essence of the proposal that will be put by the Commonwealth government at the police ministers meeting on Friday. We need an effective registration system and we will be pushing very strongly for that. Of course, removing these firearms will have a cost.

ANSWER.PARA: In response to Senator Spindler's question, or that part of it in relation to sales tax collections, I can advise him that, in the latest taxation statistics, the value of sales tax collections in the 1994-95 financial year for sporting equipment, arms and ammunition is reported to be $132 million. I am advised by the Taxation Office that, whilst it is difficult to estimate the value of collections for firearms and ammunition separately, the value of collections in 1994-95 is estimated to be in the order of $10 million. The Prime Minister in his statement yesterday has indicated that he believes it is appropriate that the cost of removing the firearms be borne by the entire community rather than just gun owners, and the Commonwealth will be considering options in conjunction with the states and territories for financing fair compensation to gun owners.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer. I would put on record that the Democrats do not wish to indicate by this question that they are opposing a levy; on the contrary, the Democrats would support a levy. But we are concerned to ensure that the buyback scheme is entirely comprehensive, Minister. Hence, it is important for you to indicate the government's support for other sources of income for it as well. Would you please confirm that this particular option will be considered?

—I can only repeat to Senator Spindler that there are obviously a range of options in relation to the financing of fair compensation in this matter, and that the Commonwealth will be considering that range of options in conjunction with the states and territories.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: National Board of Employment, Education and Training

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Given that you propose to abolish the National Board of Employment, Education and Training, how do you propose to obtain independent, coordinated and cross-sectoral advice on a range of education, employment and training issues that the board currently advises on?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —This might surprise you, Senator, but Senator Hill, who wrote the policy that decided that NBEET would be disposed of, has some very good ideas—and I hesitate to say, but a lack of modesty today forces me to do so, that since taking this portfolio I myself have added a few. I am absolutely satisfied that the policy of disposing of NBEET and strengthening the independence of the Higher Education Council and the Australian Research Council is the appropriate way to go.

ANSWER.PARA: I had a discussion this morning with Professor Brennan. I have had discussions with a number of people about this matter. I have no intention of rushing and making a mistake in the design. I agree that the past design was faulty and the new design has to be very much better. I am satisfied that we need to find a way to give the Higher Education Council a greater independence, and we also need that for the Australian Research Council. We also have to find a way to get, in all probability, some tie between—sorry, Senator, if I am interrupting your discussion with Senator Sherry by giving an answer to the question that you asked.

TALK.START.PARA: —He knows a lot more about this than you can know.

—I am really sorry. The sad thing for you, Sport, is that you lost government. You were in government. You were down the end of the chamber down here, and you were probably looking to come up here. Now you have come up on top of your other colleagues—experienced senators, like Senator Collins, Senator Cook, Senator Bolkus and Senator Schacht; they have all been shoved down. But the fact that you are up there does not mean that you can run the show—because your party lost.

ANSWER.PARA: So you say to me, Senator, that you have a lot of good ideas on this. Let me indicate to you that, unlike your party, our party has an open mind. If you have a lot of good ideas on how to improve the situation, I would be more than happy to hear from you—more than happy to hear from you, if you have some good suggestions to put in.

But the bottom line of my answer is: we were dissatisfied with the arrangements as they were. We clearly indicated in our policy that we would dispose of NBEET, and we clearly indicated in our policy that we would seek to enhance the Australian Research Council and the Higher Education Council. Am I rushing to a first judgment on the best way to do that? No. If I can take it that you have some ideas that you would be happy to offer the government, I would be more than happy to listen. If your ideas are good, they will be implemented; if they are not, they will be discarded. The sad thing for you is that you are in opposition, and the only way you can get your ideas implemented is by sharing them with us.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Given the minister's answer, could she please indicate to us: what is the cost of the proposed alternative advice that you are seeking; what confidence can the Senate have that such advice would be broadly, rather than narrowly, based; what is the cost of providing the advice; and, further, given that you are not rushing into this matter, could you please indicate to the Senate why this particular proposal is listed on the government's proposed business for the winter sittings?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —It is perfectly simple, actually. Perhaps I will run it past you just one more time, and I will try to speak slowly. I thought I used pretty clear words. But if I speak slowly, perhaps you will understand.

ANSWER.PARA: We have made the decision to dispose of NBEET, and we are going to do it. Legislation will be put before parliament to do that. The Higher Education Council and the ARC will be, in an administrative sense only, in a holding pattern. They will be continuing with their work until any changes we want to make are clarified. We will do that after broad discussion in the community. A discussion paper will be released so that more people than just you, Senator, can offer their views and we can get to something that all the interested parties have had the opportunity to have a say in. Of course, you then will have another opportunity to have a say, because legislation with respect to those matters will come into this place.

So all in good time, you will have the opportunity to have your say. I have invited you to give your opinions to me, you will have the opportunity to comment on the discussion paper, and you will have the opportunity to express your views in this place when the legislation comes forward. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

—It is true, Senator Vanstone, and unfortunately we have it on board. SPEECH.PARA: When she was asked a question by Senator Bolkus in relation to the Family Court of Australia there was again no answer apart from an unwarranted attack on the previous Prime Minister. There was no answer to the question and no answer to the supplementary question. That is the pattern of Senator Vanstone. During her answer to a supplementary question from Senator Bolkus last week she said this, `One of the skills you will learn is not to bother asking a supplementary question if it is quite clear that you are not going to get any further information.'

BREAK.PARA: That is exactly the same principle that we saw Senator Vanstone invoke today. The answer was, `We won't give it to you if we don't want to.' Senator Vanstone is yet to break her duck in this parliament. Senator Vanstone is yet to give a cogent answer, an objective answer, or an effective answer to any question that has been asked by a non‐government senator in this chamber. TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I am not deaf. Would you request the Leader of the Opposition to speak in a normal voice?

You do not have a clue about your own department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Your performance is a disgrace. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on the same matter. In the first four question times in this session we have seen Senator Vanstone treating this chamber with absolute contempt: not only failing to answer questions but making all sorts of gratuitous comments across the chamber to hide the fact that she has absolutely no grasp of either the portfolio that she represents in this chamber on her own behalf or on behalf of the Attorney‐General. She has no confidence whatsoever.

SPEECH.PARA: We on this side of the chamber asked Senator Vanstone a question on the first day of sitting as to the fitness or otherwise of a senator to sit in this chamber. Is she trying to delay her answer until 14 May comes and goes—the time by which a senator can be challenged in the Court of Disputed Returns?
