KOONGARRA PROJECT AREA REPEAL BILL 1996.

On 22nd February, 1988 my former colleague, Senator Paul Maclean introduced the Koongarra Project Area Repeal Bill. Unfortunately the former Labor Government did not take the opportunity to repeal this act, even though it was clear an agreement had not been reached with the traditional owners and the Minister in 14 years and even though the former Government had a policy which would prevent the mine ever opening under their leadership and even though it is just patently wrong to attempt to extract uranium from such a significant and special place.

Now with the possibility of more uranium mining rearing its ugly head again in the Kakadu World Heritage Area, the Democrats are re‐introducing this bill as we believe it is vitally important this mine does not go ahead.

The purpose of this bill is, clearly, to repeal the Koongarra Project Area Act of 1981. As honourable senators will be aware, the Koongarra Project Area Act was submitted to this House on 12 June 1981-the last day on which the Government then led by Mr Fraser had the number of senators needed to force any bill it wished through the Parliament.

The Koongarra Project Area Bill was brought on with total disregard for the sections of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975 which provide for at least 15 sitting days notice to both Houses of Parliament, and 60 days for public comment after publication in the Commonwealth Gazette of any intention by any government to remove land from a national park.

This Parliament now has the opportunity to correct that act of piracy by repealing the Koongarra Project Area Act and thereby returning the Koongarra mining project area to the Kakadu National Park and World Heritage Area..

Honourable senators will be interested and, I am sure, relieved, to hear that section 3 of the Koongarra Project Area Act has not yet been proclaimed. Section 3 is that section of the act which actually excises the Koongarra mining project area from the national park. It is therefore most appropriate that the Koongarra Project Area Act 1981 be repealed immediately, while its repeal is a simple and straightforward one.

In the Koongarra area as it now stands, the Australian people have an invaluable treasure-an area of unique scenic, archaeological and ecological importance. The Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry Second Report 1977-known as the Fox report-opposed the exploitation of the Koongarra deposit, and suggested that the South Alligator River catchment area was the most suitable large total river catchment for inclusion in the Kakadu National Park.
Any mining at Koongarra would cause irreparable damage to the South Alligator River catchment area. The Fox Commission also pointed out that the Koongarra area is:

"located upstream from the extremely valuable Woolwonga Wildlife Sanctuary . . . the Woolwonga area is so valuable ecologically that we would oppose in principle any mining development upstream of it". (Fox Report)

If the Government allowed any damage to the Woolwonga area, which is now incorporated in Kakadu National Park, it would be abrogating its responsibilities under the Convention on Wetlands of International Importance and Australia's agreement with Japan for the Protection of Migratory Birds in Danger of Extinction. Even the original mining company's environmental impact statement described the Koongarra area as:

"containing a most diversified range of ecosystems, wildlife, wetlands and landscape formations not found elsewhere in the continent . . . the region has a number of Aboriginal sacred areas, relics and features. The ancient Aboriginal art work found in many of the caves and galleries of the rock outcrops has no equivalent in Australia". (from Noranda Ltd)

Indeed, the archaeological value of the prehistoric sites of Kakadu National Park, of which Nourlangie Rock is one of the most important, is massive. In a report on archaeological research in Kakadu National Park, leading Australian archaeologist, Dr Rhys Jones, and Tia Negerevich wrote:

"Along the base of the great cliffs . . . are rock shelters which constitute one of the world's most important storehouses of information about the prehistory and the art of hunting and gathering man. In terms of the number and age of occupied rock shelters, and the staggering profusion and antiquity of the brilliant rock art sites, the Kakadu area can be compared with some of the classic archaeological locations of the world.

. . . in Kakadu, the Aboriginal owners are the direct descendants of the people who lived in the rock shelters and who painted the art . . . The conjunction of living Aboriginal traditions, and extremely diverse and rich landscape and the wealth of archaeological sites, some with proven antiquity back to 23,000 years ago, makes the Kakadu a key zone for research into the prehistory of Australia." (Rhys Jones and Negerevich)

The writers liken the importance of the Kakadu sites to the Dordogne cave paintings in France, with the added factor of the direct descent of the traditional owners from the inhabitants of the area over 23,000 years ago.

The unique beauty of the Koongarra area, including Nourlangie Rock, the South Alligator River catchment area and the Nourlangie Creek catchment area, would be destroyed forever if mining were allowed to take place at Koongarra. Explosions from a mine site there might cause falls or slides of segments of Nourlangie Rock itself-one of the most significant archaeological sites in Australia.

There would be a significant increase of dust in the atmosphere, and that, as well as other adverse ecological effects of such a mine would cause direct degradation of the archaeological sites, as well as the indirect degradation caused by scars on the landscape from roads to the mining area, noise and air pollution, and pollution of the water table. None of this must be allowed to occur. With the repeal of the Koongarra Project Area Act 1981, the area will be returned to its rightful place in Kakadu National Park. The area is of such obvious international significance that its inclusion in the World Heritage listing for Kakadu is utterly appropriate.

There were very strong views put forward in this place in June 1981 by Australian Labor Party (ALP) senators when the original bill was brought on. They were horrified that such a unique area should be excised from a national park so it could be destroyed in the commercial interests of a mining company-and at the time Canadian-owned mining company at that.

We say it is no different now that the mineral lease is now owned by a French Company,—Cogema. On that occasion all Labor senators joined with the Australian Democrats to vote against the bill. I am sure, with the ALP speaking so strongly against any new mining in this area, they will be consistent in their attitude. I am confident the bill will also gain the support of the Greens and I challenge the Government to go beyond the cargo cult mentality which some in the mining industry are attempting to persuade you to adopt and join with on this issue to replace this beautiful area in the middle of the Kakadu World Heritage Area and preserve it for future generations to enjoy and to wonder at.
I commend the bill to the Senate, and I look forward to its speedy passage through both houses.
PROHIBITION OF EXPORTATION OF URANIUM (CUSTOMS ACT AMENDMENT) BILL 1996

This bill is to prevent the export of all uranium from Australian shores. The Australian Democrats believe this is very important because it is only through not taking any part in the nuclear fuel or weapons cycle that we can be sure, certain sure that our country is not contributing to the whole nuclear problem.

It is no good to say, we only produce uranium ore, or we only produce it for power, or our uranium can't go into weapons. The fact of the matter is, we are producing a material which will become waste which has to be dealt with and will last many thousands of years. The fact of the matter also is that there are no guarantees, no absolute guarantees that Australian Uranium is not being enriched, flag swapped and used in weapons manufacture.

We must be responsible with the uranium in this country, we must admit that it is producing waste and the effects of that waste in biological and environmental damage are measured in a geological time scale, not a human time scale.
I want to go into a little detail on radioactive waste to explain our cause for concern.

The management and final disposal of radioactive waste has presented some of the most profound and enduring difficulties for nuclear power and uranium mining. This is in start contrast to the great improvements in managing and disposing of almost all other types of wastes created by modern societies.

Radioactivity comes from the alpha, gamma or beta radiation or a combination of these invisible rays arising from the decay of unstable atoms in the waste. Cancers or birth defects may therefore arise from human exposure to radioactive waste. Also radioactive waste particles can take from a short time to a very long or geological (many tens of thousands of years) time frame to decay to harmless substances.

Wastes from nuclear reactors have some of the very longest lived wastes and so need to be kept isolated from the biosphere for hundreds of thousands of years. It is virtually impossible to guarantee there will never be leaks, cracks, earthquakes, breakdown in maintenance or other occurrences which could cause leakage of the waste material in the time scale needed. Both ocean and land style disposal are being used globally for attempted disposal and there are many, many problems.
A prize for the dirtiest most dangerous place for radioactive waste would have to be shared between Hanford, in Washington State US and Mayak near the Ural Mountains in the former USSR.

Records in Hanford are poor, but there are more than four million litres of partly liquid, high level nuclear wastes held in 177 tanks, some of which have leaked and some of which burp poisonous and radioactive gases. About 1 tonne of plutonium is believed to be scattered under the sand at Hanford, together with thousands of tonnes of other solid wastes. A total of 760 billion litres of non high‐level radioactive wastes were also stored or simply poured into the ground.

The total contaminated soils and associated groundwater amounts to about one billion tonnes. Estimated costs of cleaning up Hanford, which of course has not been done, are thought to lie between $50 billion and $200 billion. The US General Accounting Office states that the total bill for remediating all of the country's nuclear weapons manufacturing sites could reach one trillion dollars.

Mayak is the official name for a 200 square kilometre secret nuclear complex 80 kilometres north of the Russian city of Chelyabinsk. Little was known by ordinary Russians or the West of the nature of Mayak until 1989, when the authorities admitted to a disastrous explosion in a nuclear waste container in 1957. The explosion contami nated 217 villages with 20 million curies of radioactivity.

Routine methods of nuclear disposal were just as dangerous. From 1950‐51 about 70 million cubic meters of waste were simply poured into the nearby Techa River (about 2.5 million curies). Tens of thousands of people downstream received doses greater than those received at Chernobyl. The now evaporated Lake Karachai was used for a Mayak dump for 30 years and is estimated to contain one billion curies of radiation.

The nuclear problem in old USSR countries is much more extensive than at Mayak alone. There are thought to be hundreds of `hot spots' in Moscow due to secret nuclear work there. There are two other major reprocessing sites in the former soviet union besides Mayak, Tomsk—7 and Krasnoyarsk—26 with their associated wastes. The Russians have poured high level wastes in a free state down deep wells. And of course there has been much recent attention ton their use of sea dumping.

There are 407 nuclear reactors associated with 235 nuclear ships which produce 20,000 cubic metres of liquid radioactive wastes per year and 6,000 cubic metres of solid waste. Some 35,000 spent fuel assemblies are reported as being stored on land and at sea. In all the former Soviet Union has dumped twice as much radioactivity into the sea as all other countries put together.

I would also anticipate an argument from the Government that our uranium is needed to fill a gap in the increasing demand for uranium for the power industry. However our information is that the industry is actually contracting.

Between 1994‐2000 approximately 60 reactors globally will be past their design lifespan. There are 48 new reactors in the pipeline which are supposedly coming on stream between 1994‐2000. Of the 48 planned perhaps as many as one third have financial or political problems and may not ever be completed. However there are also existing reactors being decommissioned which will be past their design lifespan. For example 10 plants in the US, 20 in the UK, 5 in Japan and 3 in Germany will be past their design lifespans Even assuming all 48 overcome financial and political problems there will still be 12 fewer by the year 2000 than there are now. Therefore reactor numbers and subsequently nuclear power is actually decreasing.

The current demand for uranium is about 60,000 tonnes per year globally taking into account the fact that new reactors initially use more because a full core load is needed. Supply at present is about 30,000 tonnes per year because a number of mines in Canada, the US, Australia and Kazakhstan operate at 50% or less capacity. This is offset by large stockpiles and large quantities of enriched (in some cases up to 95%) uranium on the marked from the USSR (between 500 and 700 tonnes) and the USA (600 tonnes).

The Indonesian Government is reported to be considering a nuclear power program of up to 12 reactors to meet the quickly increasing demand for power from its 120 million citizens. Australia, the US, Canada and Japan are all vying for an active role in Indonesia's nuclear power industry. Concerns expressed both from within Indonesia and international groups particularly point to the danger of earthquakes and volcanoes in such a volatile geological area and the capacity of the Indonesians to use best possible and expensive practice to maintain all aspects of the nuclear fuel cycle.
Waste could be earmarked for storage on uninhabited islands. Wahli, the environmental group in Java recently claimed 77% of the population oppose the construction of nuclear power plants.

The first nuclear reactor planned for Indonesia is scheduled for construction in 1998 near Mount Muria on the north coast of central Java. This is a dormant volcano (like Mt Pinatubo) in one of the most seismically active regions in the world.

There have been and will continue to be accidents at nuclear power facilities. On the 8th August 1995, the Sydney Morning Herald reported that from the beginning of 1992 to May 1995 there were 7,698 incidents in Russian nuclear power plants and that safety standards had not improved since 1963. The Australian Government supporting 12 nuclear power plants in Indonesia is like supporting any other nuclear power plant development, an act of madness.
Nuclear Terrorism

Finally, we must remember that our uranium doesn't get special treatment in the case of theft or use for terrorism. This century has seen the proliferation of several terrorist friendly technologies—plastic explosives are one example. However some of the most potentially dangerous technologies are those associated with nuclear, biological and chemical means of warfare. Of these the worst scenarios are where terrorists achieve control over nuclear facilities, material or even weapons. On 20th March 1996, speaking at a US Senate Permanent Investigations Subcommittee, the Director of Central Intelligence, John Duetch said

"The chilling reality is that nuclear material and technologies are more accessible now than at any other time in history. . . This problem can begin in any state where there are nuclear materials, reactors or fuel cycle facilities."

Possession of functional nuclear weapons is not necessary to pose serious security threats to civilian populations. Highly radioactive material of any sort such as from a nuclear power station, will suffice to contaminate large areas if a means of distribu tion can be found. Terrorist attacks on nuclear facilities (eg reactors, high level waste dumps) could cause large numbers of causalities and render some areas uninhabitable.

The disaster at Chernobyl was an accident; the deliberate destruction of an operating reactor's containment could have equally catastrophic consequences. These are problems recognised by many Governments in the world.

To sum up, there are simply no good arguments for Australia to sell its uranium overseas. To use the fatuous notion that if we don't sell it, some other country will and we won't get the money is like saying we should sell cocaine, or the Cartels in Colombia will sell it and we won't get the money. There are problems with the entire nuclear cycle, from producing and transporting the ore, to enrichment, to use, to waste and to disposal or use of that waste. And those problems are measured in our very genetic blueprints and in a timescale most of us can't imagine.
The Australian Democrats implore the Senate to deal responsibly with this vitally important legislation and ensure its speedy passage through both houses.
URANIUM MINING IN AUSTRALIAN WORLD HERITAGE PROPERTIES (PROHIBITION) BILL 1996.

The purpose of this act is to spell out the terms of a prohibited activity in any part of a World Heritage Area. For the purposes of this act a prohibited activity means the mining, extraction, treatment and transport of any uranium or uranium bearing ore.
This bill is an attempt to protect, in particular, the Kakadu World Heritage Area from further uranium mining or milling, and from any transportation of uranium ore.

The strength of this act lies in its sensible and reasonable aims which are to prevent the tainting of a World Heritage Area by uranium mining and associated activities. Having a uranium mine in a World Heritage Area is like having a large industrial grease trap in the concert hall of the Sydney Opera House. A rubbish dump in a church. A chemical factory in the Healesville sanctuary.

For the purposes of this bill I will put aside all the arguments about the risks associated with nuclear power. Put aside arguments about our uranium finding its way into nuclear weapons, and all the problems associated with disposal and long term management of nuclear waste from enriched sources.
This bill is specifically about protecting superb world heritage areas, and in particular Kakadu World Heritage area, from the risks associated with uranium mining.

Kakadu is a magnificent National Park and World Heritage Area in the Northern Territory. It is one of only 17 World Heritage sites out of 440 globally which were inscribed for both outstanding natural and cultural heritage values according to the strict international criteria.
Kakadu was inscribed on the World Heritage register in 3 stages, 1981, 1987 and stage 3 in 1992 which included the controversial Coronation Hill area.

It contains magnificent wetlands, representatives of most of Australia's bird species. It protects almost the entire South Alligator River Catchment area, and is an area of great and abundant diversity.

From a cultural perspective I have viewed extensive rock art galleries there with art possibly dating back 40,000 years. It is a place where Aboriginal people live and interact with their environment and their heritage. Many Aboriginal people have told the Democrats over the years that it is a place they believe is too precious to be disrupted for a uranium mine.

The Government will argue that the local Aboriginal people will receive great benefits from the mine. Those benefits are supposed to flow from a minority percentage of the royalty equivalents. But in effect these payments are used to make up for the neglect by Territory and Commonwealth governments.

They are used as a justification for not giving funding from other sources for what could be best described as citizenship rights; for example basic health services, housing and basic infrastructure. The Northern Territory government and the Commonwealth governments have demonstrably and continually abrogated their responsibility for the traditional owners of Kakadu.

It is morally bankrupt for any Government in this nation, State, territory or Federal, to pressure Aboriginal people to agree to a uranium mine on their land so they can have some hope of getting basic services.

One of the many concerns about uranium mining is the potential effect of radioactive spills of contaminated water and its mobilisation into the environment, particularly downstream in catchment areas.

The Government will also try to say there are no safety or environmental problems with mining uranium, they will say it is OK to take a chance on more mines in Kakadu. But remember this is a World Heritage area and you don't use Ming vases in a juggling act.
The 1985/86 Annual Report of the Office of the Supervising Scientist states:
"Disposal of uranium mill tailings in surface dams, no matter how well stabilised and protected, almost certainly involves the acceptance of eventual tailings release into the environment.

While this risk may be reduced. . . it is unlikely that any containment structure could remain totally impregnable to the natural processes of slow erosion over periods comparable to several half lives of the longest lived isotopes retained in the tailings"

Ranger and Narbarlek and the Jabiluka and Koongara deposits are in high rainfall catchment areas. Tailings from uranium extraction contain more than 70% of the radioactivity of the original ore. Impacts from uranium mining and milling are measured in a geological time scale as half lives of radio nucleides and in many cases are measured in tens of thousands of years.

Unauthorised and authorised releases or spills have occurred at both Ranger and Narbarlek in the past. A notable spill at Narbarlek occurred as a result of a split in a pipeline allowing about 5kgs of tailings slurry to spray outside the Narbarlek restricted release zone.

In early 1995 during a heavy wet season, the management of Ranger applied to release contaminated water from Retention Pond 2 in the restricted release zone, which would have flowed into the Magela Creek system.

The Traditional owners of an area of Arnham Land downstream from the mine in the Magela Creek region objected strongly to the release and sought an injunction to prevent the release from the Northern Territory Supreme Court which was heard on the 16th March.

The Judge rejected the application for a permanent injunction and effectively paved the way for the release of contaminated water saying `someone' had to explain to the traditional owners and affected peoples downstream that the releases were safe, because the scientists said so.

The traditional owners point out that if this contaminated radioactive water was to be put in the Sydney water and food supply there would be outrage, yet they were expected to support such a release. Fortunately the time involved in the court proceedings meant that the flow of the creek had slowed to the point that the Office of the Supervising Scientist advised against the release.

It is still possible that the Ranger management (or even the managers of other mines should they be approved by the Coalition Government), will request to release contaminated water in the future as it has stated it has only deferred the release.

This controversy followed earlier requests for release of contaminated water in 1986/87, and 1989. The 1989 incident Ranger released water by allowing it to overflow to a spillway into Djalk mara Billabong using the rationale that the Billabong would act as a filter for the water.
Despite the Office of the Supervising Scientist refusing to give approval, the Northern Territory Government did, and the release went ahead.
Following this incident, the Office of the Supervising Scientist released this statement in their 1988/89 report:

"Over the past year or so, Ranger/ERA has shown an increasing tendency to regard certain environmental requirements as `legal technicalities' the strict application of which ERA has described as an impediment to developing the Best Practicable Technology'. Ranger has been reluctant to adhere strictly to the ER's where compliance leads to operational inconvenience, or additional expenditure and it has disregarded technical advice from the OSS resulting in a number of incidents or deliberate actions whose environmental implications are undesirable".

For all these reasons, spills and the potential for more, the effect on the Aboriginal comminutes and the effect on one of the most precious places on earth, I ask all honourable Senators in this place to forget their party and industry allegiance just for one minute.

Think of the wonderful gift the human race has been given. A unique, rich world, with clean rivers and seas, an abundance of life in all of its different forms and rich soils and resources. We have a chance, possibly unique, to protect this and to live in a way that protects it for future generations, to live simply so that others may simply live.

Think of the world you want to pass on to your children and grandchildren, the life chances you want them to have, the places you would like them to see, the experiences you would like them to enjoy. With all that in mind, let's be very clear, nuclear accidents sully and contaminate our environment and our very genetic blueprints on a time line measured in generations.

I am sure when you take the chance to honestly reflect on my words and on the content of this bill, you will all agree that Kakadu is too precious to put at risk, too precious to expose to further radioactive waste.
I commend this bill to the Senate and I look forward to both houses fully enshrining the protection of World Heritage areas, and in particular Kakadu, from uranium mining.

The speech read as follows—
This bill is another example of the bipartisan approach of this government to improving the health of all Australians.

This particular bill has had an increasingly tortuous history since it was first introduced into parliament by the former government in early 1995. The bill was initially part of an omnibus bill, the Human Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No.1) 1995, which was subsequently divided into more manageable parts.

This bill incorporates and re-introduces the provisions of the Therapeutic Goods Amendment Bill 1995 which was passed by both sides of the House of Representatives on 28 September 1995, but was still awaiting consideration by the Senate when the parliament rose at the conclusion of the 1995 sittings. As a result, over 600 applications for listing particular products for supply in Australia have been delayed, which has incurred considerable financial distress for the applicants waiting to have their products listed prior to marketing. These applications comprise relatively simple, low risk products such as vitamin, mineral, herbal, homeopathic and sunscreen products.
The government believes that, given the long gestation of this bill, it is in the public interest to relieve this financial distress as soon as possible.

The government welcomes manageable legislation and particularly welcomes the innovations contained in this bill. We note that last year the then government and now opposition, who first moved this bill, also actively promoted the measures contained in this legislation.

This bill has now been reintroduced for the third time in this place in a form which will facilitate its passage by accommodating the needs of the Senate as well as the conventions of the House. This legislation is brought forward by the government as a priority bill for introduction and passage in this session.

The provisions of this bill will establish a new accelerated process for placing listable drugs supplied in Australia on the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods, ARTG. This new process will significantly reduce product approval times to a matter of weeks, without in any way affecting the quality or safety of the medicinal products.

Under the new scheme, products must meet the same criteria as currently exists. These criteria include a statement that the goods are safe for the purposes for which they are to be used, being the purposes identified in the application for marketing, and not other purposes which go beyond the accepted indications for the therapeutic uses of the product.

The bill also provides a much better definition of some poorly understood aspects of the National Regulatory Scheme for Therapeutic Goods, which have been identified in its first five years of operation.

A mechanism to address shortages or lack of essential drugs required by the public in emergency situations has also been included, along with amendments that update and consolidate in a new part of the act, the entry, search and warrant powers to enforce the legislation.

This bill introduces changes to align the monetary penalties in the current legislation with the "penalty units" classification used in other commonwealth regulatory legislation, as well as closing a gap in the current scheme, in regard to the removal of illegal therapeutic goods of unknown quality, safety or efficacy from the market.

Also included in this bill are provisions to permit warrentless entry of premises to seize goods, but limiting this power to situations where there is an imminent public health risk of death or serious injury, and where there are reasonable grounds for believing that illegal activity is taking place.

A definition for "food" has been inserted to clarify the interface between food and drugs. Problems have arisen from the present definition of "therapeutic goods" which excludes "food" but fails to define the term. What constitutes "food" in the bill will be linked to the presentation and promotion of a product in the market. The words "prescribed dose" and "frequency of administration" included in the definition are to be read in a pharmaceutical sense, and are not intended to encompass serving suggestions applied to or normally associated with food and beverages.

The appeal provisions in the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 relating to the review of decisions to register therapeutic goods have also been tightened. This will ensure that technical and scientific data that should be lodged in connection with a general marketing application, will be evaluated before a review on merits is undertaken by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

The bill also corrects a defect in the legislation regarding the ability of the secretary to approve the inclusion on the ARTG of products for export only where those products have been refused marketing approval in Australia. In these circumstances the secretary is currently empowered to require confirmation that the relevant authority of the country to which the goods are to be exported is willing to accept the goods. This power is however limited to goods that have been manufactured in Australia for export only, and does not extend to products imported into Australia solely for re-export. The bill proposes that this provision be amended to ensure that the secretary's ability to require confirmation from Australia's trading partners of their willingness to accept goods refused marketing approval in Australia, extends to all products, irrespective of whether they have been manufactured in Australia or elsewhere.
Overall, this bill will benefit Australia's therapeutic industry and further enhance Australia's role as a leader in drug evaluation, registration and regulation in the region.
I commend this bill to the Senate.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Report No. 21 of 1995‐96—Performance Audit—The Meat Research Corporation—Management of Project Fututech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

In moving this motion, I should just make a couple of comments. I understand honourable senators on the other side and maybe other honourable senators here might wish to comment on this report more fully. Fututech has been a matter of great interest to me and other senators from Queensland because it was supposed to be trialled in a commercial process at Kilcoy, which is not far outside Brisbane. Kilcoy is one of the smaller meatworks which is not controlled by a major chain in the same way that AMH has controlled meatworks through large portions of Queensland and elsewhere.

Fututech offered a wonderful opportunity for Kilcoy to progress and also for us to start to close some of the major problems that we have had in terms of inefficiency compared with our competitors overseas. Everybody would appreciate the fact that one of the grave difficulties that we have had in the primary industry sector is getting more value back to the people who produce the original product. I speak as somebody who suffers the consequences of our not being able to get value for money for producers because, when you sell animals for slaughter, the meatworks give the price based on the price for beef and the processing cost.

Processing costs in Australian abattoirs have been unacceptably high, compared even with New Zealand. Everybody thought that Fututech was a wonderful opportunity for us to reduce the processing cost. The idea was that these animals would go through an automated slaughter process. What became apparent as the trials went on was that the process was not working. The idea that these animals would be automatically killed just was not happening. There are numerous stories about the consequences of the failure of the automated slaughtering process to kill the animal in a fashion that the carcass could then be processed.

I think Senator Parer would be aware that the carcasses were unfit for processing after they had gone through the process. That did not help anybody at all. I personally was not aware that, at the time at which this process was being followed, there was actually a commercial agreement between the Meat Research Corporation and Kilcoy meatworks. Everybody thought that this was just a convenient trial which had been done at Kilcoy with the concurrence of the company. Nobody knew that there was in fact a commercial obligation on the Meat Research Corporation to provide what is described in the summary as a fully operational commercial slaughter line based on commercial criteria.

The Auditor-General found that, in despite of that commercial obligation, the process was commenced without the rigour one would normally associate with research. There were unresolved technical problems and there had been a failure in a commercial sense to quantify the costs and benefits or to properly define the market potential. In other words, you had a great idea, a great concept, `Let's have an automated slaughter line for beef cattle.' But instead of progressing it to a more finished stage, the Meat Research Corporation hopped in and said, `We are going to install this line at Kilcoy,' and entered into a commercial obligation to produce a line which could be used for commercial production. So when the prototype did not work—and it was not fit to work when it was installed, because it was still in the developmental stage—the Meat Research Corporation entered into a situation where it had a massive commercial exposure to the Kilcoy meatworks.

That has seen the cost blow out from $2.2 million, which was the estimated cost of the Kilcoy portion of the Fututech program, to $20 million for that portion of the program. That is half of the $40 million which was expended in relation to Fututech. Poor financial management has cost the Meat Research Corporation a lot of money. That poor financial management and poor commercial management has, moreover, cost producers a lot of money because the blowout of $18 million is funded to the tune of $9 million by contributions from the industry. I think this is very unfortunate. I would have hoped that the situation would not have been what it clearly was and is exposed in this report as having been.

Having said that, I am also very pleased to see that the Meat Research Corporation has taken on all the recommendations contained in the Auditor‐General's report. We might consider some of them to be fairly fundamental, but obviously they were not followed. For example, ANAO recommendation No. 1 states that before a decision to commercialise a process is made, rigorous documentation and analysis of technical data should be undertaken on all research projects to support the assurance that estimated performance improvement and cost savings can be achieved. That is pretty simple. If you were a commercial operator, you would do that. The Meat Research Corporation, for some inexplicable reason, has failed to do that. I would hope that not only do they agree to accept the recommendation, but they to start to put it into practice from now on, because that is obviously a matter of great significance.
I could go on about the other recommendations contained in the report but I do not want to delay the chamber further. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 6 May.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarrette, Sen Christabel

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise for inconveniencing the chamber by not arriving yesterday, due to a diversion to Launceston. I also explain that because my office did not receive a copy of the bill until yesterday, they were not able to change all the numbers on the amendments that I had circulated last session. I need to check whether my colleagues have received the current amendments which have been circulated in the name of the Greens.
—I do not think your amendments have been received. I do not have them.

—I have an indication they are about to be received. There are some changes to the latter part of the amendments—that is, Nos 24, 25, et cetera. The first amendments are identical to the ones circulated on the last day of the last session. The only things that have been changed are the numbers. I will speak to my first amendment.

—Your first amendment indicates that you wish to vote against something. The question before the chamber will be that schedule 1, item 4, page 3, lines 26 to 27, be approved, and you will speak against that.

—I wish to speak against that item. The reason is that it proposes a change to the aims of the act and includes phrases that specifically mention article 11 of the convention. The view of the Greens is that this gives undue precedence to article 11 agreements, which are a very small part of the convention.

SPEECH.PARA: Article 11 is a tiny section of the convention that allows the minister to enter into a bilateral agreement with another country to determine that a hazardous waste is not a hazardous waste. This is by no means the overall aim of the Basel convention and therefore should not be stated as one of the overall aims of this bill. For that reason, the Greens will be opposing this item.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —This and a number of amendments of the Australian Democrats and, I think, some of the amendments of the Greens (WA), relate to the issue of article 11 agreements. I think, as Senator Chamarette said as she sat down, it is really a debate about the legitimacy of such agreements and the place for dealing with those agreements within this amending bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps I could make a few general comments on article 11 agreements to help clarify the government's position. Article 11 of the Basel Convention provides that parties may enter into agreements with other parties and/or non‐parties providing for the trans‐boundary movements of hazardous wastes. An article 11 agreement may contain different rules to those in the convention. However, article 11.1 shall stipulate the provisions which are not less environmentally sound than those in the convention. In other words, the source of the agreement is, Senator Chamarette, the convention itself and the convention provides for the setting up of these agreements.

So, I guess, in some ways your argument is an argument against the convention itself. We are a party to the convention and we are trying to put in place legislation that provides for Australia meeting its commitments thereunder, which includes not only the transfer of wastes under the convention proper but also under agreements that are set up under article 11.

But the point I was seeking to make was that, although there may be separate rules for such an article 11 agreement, the fact that they shall be not less environmentally sound has the effect that the agreement cannot therefore undermine the convention. I should have thought that that would have given Senator Chamarette some comfort.

The Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill provides for the minister to declare an agreement to be an article 11 agreement for the purposes of this act, which is section 4G. Regulations to be made to give effect to article 11 agreements are dealt with in sections 16C to E. A substance is to be deemed to not be hazardous waste if it is covered by an article 11 agreement under which the substance is not regulated. That just simply distinguishes substances that are dealt with under the article 11 agreements from those that are dealt with under the core of the convention. A substance is to be deemed to be hazardous waste under the act if it is covered by an article 11 agreement, even if it is not otherwise regulated by the act. This is under section 4F, which operates only for the purposes of the article 11 agreement.

Of course, Australia is a party to an article 11 agreement in relation to the OECD. In fact, Australia is currently a party to three article 11 arrangements. The major one of these is the OECD decision on the trans‐boundary movement of hazardous waste destined for a recovery operation, which is commonly known as the OECD council decision. As a member of the OECD, Australia is obliged to comply with the terms and conditions of the OECD council decision. I will not go into all the details of it as that would be a bit unnecessary at the moment.

The important thing is that section 4G provides the legal mechanism under which the movement of such waste can occur. So the bill before us picks up the fact that the convention provides for article 11 arrangements. Australia is already the party to three such arrangements and we need a domestic regulatory procedure to ensure compliance.

Therefore, I really cannot see the purpose of this amendment and the others related to it which would result in us not having this capacity in domestic law. I should have thought that the Greens and the Australian Democrats would have been in here calling for it. It might have been a different thing if the convention did not provide for it, but that is history.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I have now found the place. I have dealt with the argument concerning the article 11 agreement so I will not need to repeat that when we reach it in a little while.
—I do not know why they are out of order, Senator Chamarette, but the amendment you just referred to is amendment No. 6 on your list.

SPEECH.PARA: The government's aim in amending the act is predominantly to bring Australia's national legislation into line with the convention. Accordingly, definitions such as `dispose of safely', which do not appear in the convention, have been removed to make way for the more consistent and widely recognised Basel terminologies. Consequently, the bill adopts the convention definition of `environmentally sound management', which applies to all stages of the waste management process, including recycling, transport and handling. On the other hand, `disposed of safely' refers specifically to the disposal process and could be misconstrued to mean final disposal only. Such an interpretation would be inconsistent with the intention of the convention and that seems to me to be a strong argument in favour of the government's amendment and an argument that should put your mind at rest, Senator Chamarette.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats intend to support the position of the WA Greens, and it is important because the first instance in which the definition is applied is to page 14, lines 26 onwards, proposed new subsection 4G, article 11. The amendment is important because it is the first instance in the bill in which the definition is applied. Although there was a little confusion about which particular amendment we were speaking about in the first instance, Senator Chamarette is quite right in saying that the argument that needs to be rehearsed is an argument about the definition of `dispose of safely'.

SPEECH.PARA: In this case, on page 3, which is the first instance where that definition is referred to, we really need to explain why it is that such a definition should not be accepted and therefore why that definition should be opposed and why the Greens' amendment No. 1 should be supported. The argument really is about the wording of this `dispose of safely'.

PARA.BREAK: The Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) gave some indication that he believed that the wording was as the result of extensive consultation. The consultation did occur. I do not dispute that at all. The result of the consultation is this construction we find on page 14, subsection 4G, which is not what should be expected as a result of long consultation, because that whole area, 4G, allows to accrue to the minister an extraordinary discretionary power to define something as either hazardous or not hazardous according to the conveniences of the time. That is the sub stance; that is the essence of what this debate should be about.

SPEECH.PARA: The way things are defined might sound pretty, but when we read what article 11 arrangements are—`substances not classified as hazardous waste'—proposed new subsection 4G gives to the minister far too much discretionary power to allow all sorts of tricky corners to be avoided. It is those tricky corners which really bring responsible behaviour to those Australians who are operating overseas.

We are not trying to get rid of article 11 agreements completely but, in looking carefully at article 11 agreements and the method by which they can be applied, we are being very careful about what it is that the minister can and cannot define as hazardous or not. That is the reason that we disagree with the very first mention of section 4, `definition of dispose of safely', when we want to support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarrette, Sen Christabel

TALK.START.PARA: —The WA Greens acknowledge that the safe disposal of hazardous waste is the intent of the act. We think that it is outrageous to remove that. In this particular clause, which is the first time it is mentioned, the concerns about it are not so great, but we are concerned about the fact that what we are presently doing is deleting the `dispose of safely' phrase out of the entire act. That phrase relates to the purpose of the convention and is what our obligations are about. Under this bill, the object of the hazardous waste act is proposed to be:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . ensure that exported, imported or transited waste is managed in an environmentally sound manner . . .

The original act states it more specifically as `to ensure that exported or imported hazardous waste is disposed of safely'. Changing the object of the act is intended to include those matters that are termed recyclables. I understand that, and I believe it is appropriate that an act should include aspects that are intended to be covered. In one sense, it could be an important measure of strengthening the effectiveness of the act to be in accordance with the tenets of the Basel convention, as the minister has said.

BREAK.PARA: The explanatory memorandum to the bill commented that the original phrase could be misconstrued as limiting the act to control the final disposal of hazardous waste rather than controlling all the dealings of such wastes. I acknowledge that, but the reverse is also true. By the government's own argument, there are obviously areas within a given act where references to the specific are crucial to ensure every base is covered. The act would be strengthened only if the general aim of environmentally sound export, import and transit of hazardous wastes was compounded by the specific intention to also ensure their safe disposal. It is for that reason that, in our amendment, we oppose the erasing of the term `dispose of safely' from the entirety of the bill.

As outlined in section 5 of the principal act, this phrase has a very important and specific definition that is necessary to control the dumping of hazardous wastes, and the assurance that hazardous wastes will be disposed of safely is a central aim of the Basel convention. No other term—certainly not one as unspecific as `the way in which hazardous waste is to be dealt with after export'—ensures safe disposal in the same way.

It seems ridiculous that, in a bill that is supposed to expand the objects of the principal act to encompass Australia's obligations under the Basel convention, the main aim of the principal act is quietly erased from the register. We believe that ensuring environmentally sound management for hazardous wastes, consistent with Australia's international obligations, also means safe disposal of those wastes, and that intention should be spelt out without compromise.

Therefore, we reject wholeheartedly the government's intention to erase `dispose of safely' from the act and we oppose not only this proposed new section but the other proposed new sections where that erasure also occurs.
