SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I move into the body of my first speech, I would like to spend a few minutes talking about the horrific events at Port Arthur on 28 April. It is at times like these that words are absolutely inadequate to describe the sense of loss, the sense of utter bewilderment, the sense of disbelief and the sense of fundamental powerlessness that Tasmania is going through.

SPEECH.PARA: In my home state at the moment it is impossible to engage in even the most casual conversation without anyone raising this issue. There is a feeling of despondency and shock that is almost palpable that hangs over the entire state. There are few people you meet who did not know a victim, or a friend of a victim or a family member of a victim. There are few people you meet who do not express outrage and helplessness at the incomprehensible nature of what happened.

But this outrage and helplessness are expressed in almost muted tones—in tones of sorrow rather than anger. It is, frankly, heartbreaking to see this in a state like Tasmania, where the sense of community is so strong. As one of the British newspapers aptly headlined, `Where in the world is safe?' Our collective compassion and sympathy goes out to those touched in whatever way by the harrowing events of 28 April. They will live on in the minds of Tasmanians and all Australians forever.

I would like to congratulate the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) for his intervention and strong action with regard to the institution of a national approach to gun laws. The measures that have now been agreed to by all states were in the main adopted in principle early last year but were deferred at the ministerial council held somewhat ironically in Launceston last November due to the intransigence and prevarication of two state governments, sadly one of which was Tasmania.

Mr President, this is not a matter for political partisanship. One of the strongest advocates for change was the Liberal Deputy Premier of Victoria and then Minister for Police, Pat McNamara. It takes a catharsis like this to bring people to their senses, and it is with no great measure of relief and thankfulness that we now have in Tasmania a tripartite agreement on gun law reform. I would like to take this opportunity to place on record the work done by the then federal Minister for Justice, Duncan Kerr, in his valiant attempts to induce change. I am sure that he is pleased by these initiatives, tardy though they clearly are.

A positive outcome, if there is such a thing in these circumstances, is the way the Tasmanian community has drawn together and the level of nurturing and support that has been evident at all levels of Tasmanian society. In Tasmania we know the value and strength of community. Tasmanians regularly top the list for their generosity during national charity appeals. We have a strong sense of local identity, a strong sense of ourselves. Margaret Thatcher's notion that there is no such thing as society is an anathema to those of us in the Labor Party. It flies in the face of the level of societal solidarity we have seen both in Tasmania and around Australia over the last 11 days.

The fact that there is such a thing as society is clearly axiomatic. The question is: what kind of society do we want? We constantly hear references to financial, physical and human capital but rarely do we hear about social capital—the social glue that binds us together as a society. Eva Cox said in her recent delivery of the Boyer lecture series that social capital is the sum of our social connections and the levels of trust we need to maintain a truly civil society. These are the building blocks of a civil society: trust, mutuality and reciprocity. Unfortunately, there are those in society who believe the obvious path to creating a society rich in society capital is, as Eva Cox puts it, `to increase the morality in communities and the power of families—nuclear, of course—and Eureka! the problem is solved'.

We live in an era of constant change. People are afraid. They are afraid for their jobs. They are afraid for their future. When the Japanese economy goes into three consecutive quarters of negative economic growth, workers around Australia fear for their livelihoods. The internationalisation of the world economy has brought about often painful change to Australian workers. The response of governments must be the rebuilding and nurturing of communities and the reintroduction of certainty and security in people's lives and a sense of belonging. Society must become more cohesive—not less. To quote Hugh Mackay:
If we don't take urgent steps to restore the sense of community, the moral impact is long‐term. People learn their sense of values from the experience of living with each other.

The social cohesion that binds communities can, given a certain environment, have a negative effect. This can result in communities clinging together bound by fear of the different. We saw this most starkly in Queensland during the federal election, with the ugliness of racism assisting in the election of ultra right wing candidates.

The agenda of this government is becoming crystal clear. In only two months of government we have seen signs of Australians being split into economic categories by attacks on Aboriginal Australians, welfare recipients, public sector workers and unions—handy scapegoating and ideologically driven. By treating any Australian differently based on their occupation, based on their gender, based on their ethnicity and so on, we are all devalued.

For 13 years under the previous Labor government no group was singled out as being of greater or lesser significance or value. Historic initiatives such as Mabo helped demystify the different. Now we are all at risk of marginalisation based on our level of consumption, whether by necessity or by a chosen lifestyle. The value of the individual and their rights in society become defined by their financial and class status.

PARA.BREAK: Only in extreme circumstances will public services be provided by government. Look at Thatcher's Britain; look at Reagan's America. Who suffers? The young, the old, the poor and always the sick. Of course there will be a good education for your kids, if you can afford it. Of course you will get the best in health care, if you can afford it. Of course you can get the phone on, if you can afford it. We end up as consumers, not citizens. This is not the kind of Australia the next genera tion deserves. This is not the kind of legacy we should leave them.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe in publicly owned monopolies like water, electricity and telecommunications. I do not believe in privatisation of these publicly owned monopolies. Let us take Telstra for example. Sure, the coalition's policy on the initial part privatisation of Telstra was well‐documented during the election campaign. It even received resounding support from some strange sources like the Wilderness Society. Sure, this government has a mandate to govern, but it does not have a mandate to sell Telstra. Every single non-government party in this chamber pledged to oppose the Telstra privatisation. This opposition was consistent, constant and abundantly clear.

Government owned enterprises such as Telstra were developed for specific reasons. They were established and progressed through money provided by Australian taxpayers to enable certain strategic and service related needs to be met. The simple fact is that many of these public utilities relating to water, electricity and telecommunications are there because they are government owned. In many cases the private sector could not or would not have established them. Government governs for the people, and that responsibility relates fundamentally to issues of fairness, access, equity and social justice.

It so happens that a government business enterprise like Telstra is also doing very nicely from a financial perspective. In the last financial year ended June 1995 Telstra as a fully owned government business enterprise had total assets of $24 billion, produced an after-tax profit of $1.7 billion and provided a dividend to the Commonwealth of $94 million.

Forgetting all the social justice arguments and concentrating purely on profit, why on earth would you want to sell it? In 1991-92, profit was just $300 million and the dividend to the Commonwealth was $478 million. In other words, in the space of the last three years profitability has increased sixfold and the dividend to the government has doubled. All this has happened just as Telstra is taking on the Asia‐Pacific region, where opportunities are abundant.

BREAK.PARA: This profitability and expansion, I must add, have been associated with record productivity over the last three years, considerably outstripping all other industry groups with a cooperative approach between the union movement and management through the accord. This same cooperative approach also delivered an unprecedented result of no days lost through industrial disputes in the 18 months to the end of the 1995 financial year.

Let us forget again for a second about the negative effects of the privatisation of Telstra on the lives of ordinary people and regional and rural Australia. Selling Telstra is quite simply bad business. The fact that it is simply bad business is compounded when you consider that the moment one-third of Telstra is sold the government loses one-third of its dividend—$300 million per annum with the associated exponential increase in forgone revenue as the years go by.

Finally, let us turn to the social costs of a privatised Telstra. Let us have a look at Tasmania, the most ruralised state in Australia. If cross-subsidisation did not exist, people living in Burnie would have to pay around an extra $850 per annum to have the phone on, people living in Smithton would have to pay around an extra $1,140 per annum and people living on King Island would have to pay around an extra $2,200 per annum.

Let us have a look at Bass. If cross-subsidisation did not exist, people living in Launceston would pay around an extra $730 per annum, people living in Scottsdale would have to pay around an extra $1,270 per annum and people living on Flinders Island would have to pay around an extra $4,930 per annum. Let us move on to the rest of Tasmania: Queenstown, an extra $1,250 per annum; Deloraine, an extra $680 per annum; St Marys, an extra $910 per annum; Geeveston, an extra $600 per annum, and on and on.

For people living in regional and rural areas the phone is a necessity of life. For the older people in our community the phone is a necessity of life. In fact, it is the primary means of regular communication with friends, relatives and, most importantly, health services. For all of us the phone is a necessity of life. Why slug people who need it most and can afford it least?

I oppose the partial sale of Telstra, not simply as a matter of social justice and good business but also on behalf of the people of Tasmania who showed clearly in the Labor Party's strong Senate polling and in the retention of three out of the four Labor held seats that they also oppose it.

Still on the theme of regional Australia, and looking again at Tasmania, the impact of public sector cuts cannot be ignored. The first major fiscal hit already heralded by the government is significant cuts to the public sector, and the slashing of state grants. These cuts on the basis of reining in the deficit are premature, have obviously not been thought through, and will impact most of all on regional economies.

One of those regional economies—and the economy most sensitive to cuts—is the Tasmanian economy. Let me first profile our island state economy and demonstrate why the proposed federal cuts will have a devastating impact on an already struggling economy.

Until the early 1980s Tasmania was performing at least as well as the rest of Australia in terms of economic growth, employment growth and our unemployment rate. Our economy was driven by strong investment and growth in our resource based industries such as forestry, mining and agriculture. At the same time, public sector investment was strong through the progressive development of our state's hydro‐electric system. With the winding down of the hydro during the 1980s and the complete cessation of dam building several years ago, associated with a plateauing of resource based industry activity, Tasmania's economic performance began to wane.

On top of this, a state that had relied heavily on public sector employment was confronted with a budgetary debt crisis in 1990 which meant severe public sector cuts. Since 1990, over 5,000 full time equivalents have been made redundant in the public sector alone, in a total labour force of some 220,000 people.

These elements have all come together in recent years to bring Tasmania's economy to its knees. Over the past four years, while the rest of Australia has been growing at three per cent to four per cent a year in real terms, Tasmania has been struggling to average half a per cent growth. This performance has been reflected in poor employment growth—under half that of the rest of Australia, and almost entirely part time—an unemployment rate stuck at above 10 per cent and now rising again, and virtually no population growth. The writing has been on the wall for four years but it has been ignored.

While the fundamental drive for a diversified economy has to come from the state government, we simply cannot afford further reductions in employment and Commonwealth funds. Tasmania's dispersed population has always necessitated greater public sector resources to ensure that every Tasmanian receives the same level of government services as every other Australian receives. The consequence of this special need is that public sector employment has become an essential component in community economies in Tasmania.

If the government's current fiscal path is continued, it will have three major consequences. First, if Tasmania receives its share of these cuts, several hundred jobs will be lost directly and several hundred more through the multiplier effect. This will take tens of millions out of our domestic economy in wages and salaries per year and further depress domestic demand.

Second, if Tasmania is apportioned its share of a reduction in Commonwealth grants to the states, at least $50 million will be slashed per year. Service delivery and jobs will be sacrificed on the altar of economic rationalism.

PARA.BREAK: Third, cuts to Working Nation programs will have a devastating effect on the long‐term unemployed. In 1994‐95 nearly $70 million of national funds were provided to Tasmania. This was increased to $100 million in 1995‐96 in recognition of Tasmania's high level of long‐term unemployed.If it were not for Working Nation funds, Tasmania's unemployment rate would have been even higher, because most of the decrease in those unem ployed over the past three years was in the long‐term unemployed category.

BREAK.PARA: The simple fact is that these initiatives, should they proceed, will guarantee that Tasmania's unemployment rate will remain above 10 per cent into the next century. Tasmania must receive special consideration.

Before becoming a senator for Tasmania, I was state secretary of the Labor Party in that state for almost four years. The resurgence of Labor in Tasmania is a shining example of what can be done when the will to win is recovered. It underlines the fundamental difference between Labor and other political parties.
Never underestimate the Labor Party. We have over 100 years of history behind us. We have seen the bad times but we have always survived. We are at our best when our backs are against the wall.

I would like to thank every member of the Labor Party in Tasmania for their support, their tenacity and their determination. It has been an honour and a personal pleasure to work with people who care enough about the future of our society to sign on the dotted line, get active and work towards a fairer society.

I joined the ALP in 1978 and in previous incarnations spent five years working in the union movement, which taught me the value of collectivism and unity. Industrial relations is a great passion for me and I will be a strong advocate in this place of the rights of working people. I owe a great debt to the labour movement and it has been an absolute privilege to make a contribution to improving the lives of people in our community.
I would also like to thank the people of Tasmania for putting me here and I will do my level best to strongly represent the interests of this state and make sure that we get a fair go.

This year is the 250th anniversary of the Battle of Culloden, so it is worth pointing out that I was born in Scotland and came to Tasmania in the late 1960s with my parents and brothers. I come from a long line of Scottish nationalists and have shared in the anguish of my family in Scotland who have suffered under Tory government policies. Scotland has consistently voted Labour—in fact to the extent that insufficient Scottish Tory MPs have been elected to fill the Scottish cabinet. The price for that? Absolute starvation of funds, cutbacks in services, and little infrastructure spending. I am proud to say that, despite this, the Scots still keep voting Labour. I suspect that stubbornness, independence and pride are well immersed in the gene pool.

I would like to thank my partner, David Crean, a non-practising doctor of medicine and a Labor member of the upper house in Tasmania. I would particularly like to thank him for his patience in putting up with me pacing around the house during election campaigns at 3 o'clock in the morning and writing interminable lists of things to do the next day. Patience and tolerance are things he has learned the hard way in his experience with a number of members of the Tasmanian Legislative Council—particularly, I would imagine, the famous George Brookes.

A final word on another great passion: increasing the number of women in politics. I say to the coalition: congratulations on the number of women elected in the last election. I also say: be careful. Even a small swing against the coalition in the next federal poll will see most of these women go. Why? The vast majority were preselected in marginal seats. We in the Labor Party know about this. To date it is pretty much what we have done.

But, Mr President, we have done something about it. The decision at the last ALP national conference was not just about a rule change, it was about a cultural change; it was about changing a mind‐set. We will achieve our target and, increasingly, we will see women preselected into safe seats. This will not just happen in the Labor Party; it will happen in all political parties.

Someone said to me recently, `Politics is not so much a glass ceiling as a sticky floor.' Occasionally, it feels like it has been superglued. To women everywhere, this is our parliament too. Until we get to 52 per cent representation of women, it cannot truly be our parliament. So I say: pull your feet off the sticky floor and mind your head on the glass ceiling. Thank you, Mr President.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon, Sen David

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I would like to be the first to congratulate Senator Mackay on a very thoughtful and sincere speech and wish her a long and successful career in the Senate chamber. I note with pleasure that at last the standard of the Labor Party in opposition is starting to improve.

SPEECH.PARA: In my speech yesterday I devoted a major part of my time to a defence issue: accidents in the Australian Defence Force. I used the recent Senate report into the Nomad crash as a starting point. I now wish to move to the fundamental concern I have; that is, the number of serious accidents that have occurred in the ADF in recent years under Labor, and the lack of accountability in relation to those accidents.

There is a common pattern across all three services, and all three services have been similarly involved. Lives have been lost and, in most cases, no censure has been made against any individual who is standing in a position of responsibility. I hold strongly to the view that rank carries inseparably with it responsibility. I will just very quickly look at some of those accidents in the recent past.

In the air force we had the Boeing 707 accident at East Sale, which one senior air force officer described privately to me at the time as `a real Third World air force type of accident'. The inquiry into that implied that blame lay with the training captain. He had a contributory role, but the RAAF had operated this type of aircraft for 10 years and it had been in civilian service for over 30 years. The inquiry also showed that the training manuals were deficient, there was no agreed approved syllabus for endorsement training—and the aircraft and all aboard were lost in an endorsement training accident. Yet none of the relevant senior officers in the air force were held accountable for that accident.

PARA.BREAK: In the navy we have had at least two FFGs driven up on reefs. We had the dreadful situation where two sailors were left on the weather decks of a submarine when it sub merged in the Tasman Sea a couple of years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: To cite a case from the army, we had a soldier killed at Tin Can Bay just over three years ago. He was a recruit from the first intake of the ready reserve, had completed his 12 months continuous training and was on an exercise at Tin Can Bay when he was killed in a grenade accident. Despite numerous questions by me in Senate estimates, the Department of Defence has now safely exceeded the three-year statute of limitations under the Defence Force Discipline Act, and no action can be taken with respect to that incident.

In this incident the soldiers were issued with grenades and the pins were interfered with; they were crimped together. On one day they were crimped and splayed back; on the day the soldier was killed they were not even splayed back but were just crimped together. It is one of the most absolute crimes in the army to interfere with or modify ammunition or munitions in any way at all, yet the ammunition was clearly interfered with here. There was a gross breach of regulations, yet no-one was censured in any way at all. The grenades in an unsafe state were issued to the soldier; as directed, he put them in his basic pouches, which were on the front of his abdomen; and, while he was crawling to a firing point, the pin came out of one of the grenades and detonated the others, and he was killed instantly.

The army set up an AIT, a board of inquiry, and there was a coroner's inquiry, and I have read all of those. Everything in relation to that accident is minutely documented: the time, the place, who did what, who the personnel were. Yet when the inquiry was held, no-one was held to blame. Having been through grenade live‐firing exercises as a soldier myself, I find it absolutely appalling that no-one was held accountable for the loss of that life.
That is true of most of the accidents that I am referring to here: no-one was held accountable in any way at all for the accident—and that is totally unacceptable to this parliament.

BREAK.PARA: I will diverge for a moment by saying that I support the recommendation of the Senate committee into the Nomad crash that there be an extension from three years to five for the statute of limitations under the Defence Force discipline act. In not all cases but clearly in some cases, the Department of Defence has protracted, through the bureaucracy, inquiries and restricted the availability of information to families, so that no charges could be laid against people until the statute of limitations had expired.

I accept that it takes time to set up inquiries, it takes time to get witnesses, it takes time to consider all the elements in writing up the report. There is an inevitable amount of time lost in the whole of the process before you can come to conclusions about accidents. But I do believe that on some occasions, regrettably, there has been a conscious attempt to draw out the time so that no charges could ultimately be laid.

Mr President, it gives me no pleasure at all to raise this matter in public and in the Senate. I yield to no‐one in this parliament in my concern for the interests and advancement of the Australian Defence Force and the men and women who serve in it. Those concerns have been demonstrated from my first days in the parliament which now go back 18 years and, indeed, reflect a lifelong interest of mine in defence matters.

These accidents strike at the very heart of the Australian Defence Force and its capabilities. The roles and the tasks demanded of the Australian Defence Force are inherently dangerous and members of the ADF do lose their lives on active service. Military training must be realistic, so it has to have an inherently high risk in it also.

I accept that, regrettably, there will always be lives lost in military training accidents, but there must never be an avoidable or pointless loss of life and that does demand careful planning and careful execution of the exercises. Exercises have got to be properly resourced: there must be adequate funding and equipment. There has to be careful planning and supervision by experienced personnel and those personnel must take responsibility for their actions.

The very heart of this matter is that the Australian Defence Force operates as a team and, as a team, it runs on trust—absolute trust between subordinates and superiors. Soldiers, sailors and airmen put their lives on the line knowing that everything humanly possible has been done, both by their colleagues and by their superiors, to get them through. You simply cannot have servicemen or women seeing colleagues killed as a consequence of bad planning, bad management or any other form of incompetence on exercises, have no‐one charged and then expect the soldiers, the sailors and the airmen to do their duty and to obey orders.

I regret that I no longer have any confidence in the Department of Defence investigating itself in relation to accidents of this nature, and I say that with very great regret. The individual services can retain their accident investigation teams and boards of inquiry, but we do need an independent inspector‐general of accidents or its equivalent. I suggest that, where property damage over a quarter of a million dollars or, maybe, half a million dollars and/or loss of life occurs, the inspector‐general is compelled to investigate the incident.

The inspector‐general should have access to a pool of very experienced service personnel with particular expertise in the areas concerned in the inquiry, plus whatever civilian experts are deemed necessary. The crucial point, though, is that all the service personnel are ex‐service personnel totally divorced from the ADF and not dependent on it in any way at all for pensions or promotions.

The powers of the inspector‐general should be: to send for persons and documents; to require evidence to be given under oath; and to inquire into all relevant aspects of the case. Above all, the inspector‐general should have the power to make recommendations on both procedures and practices and, most importantly, to make recommendations in respect of either reward or censure of individuals involved. Those recommendations must be mandatory on the relevant service. In other words, whatever the independent inspector‐general recommends in the way of reward or punishment must be applied by the service.

One final point I want to raise is the matter of financial recompense. Legal costs today are huge. Even if the family of somebody who is killed in a Defence Force accident is not going to mount a legal challenge, the matters of looking after the interests of the deceased are very real and they are catered for by the family having legal representation at some of the hearings.

I know of one case in the very recent past where a soldier was killed on an exercise and his family paid the sum of $30,000 in legal fees although they had made no challenge. I know nothing about the family's financial status, but I suspect that was a very great financial load for the family to bear, as it would be for most people. To their credit, they have never commented on that burden in public or drawn attention to it in any way at all. I will not do so by naming them here today, but I do believe it is reasonable that the family in these circumstances should be covered for reasonable legal costs for what, hopefully, should be a very rare event.

In summary, the present system of not attributing blame to service personnel where they have fallen short of their responsibilities can no longer be sustained. Since the Department of Defence has shown it is incapable of sitting in judgment on itself, it is time to substitute an independent and experienced body to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling Senator Lundy, I remind honourable senators that this is her first speech. I ask that the normal courtesies be extended to her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to begin by thanking the people of the ACT and the Australian Labor Party for granting me the honour of representing them in the Senate. This honour followed the decision by Bob McMullan to contest the seat of Canberra, a decision endorsed by the voters of that electorate.

SPEECH.PARA: During his eight years as ACT senator, Bob forged a well‐deserved reputation as a highly effective representative of the Canberra community. This reputation was further enhanced by his service to the people of Australia as a minister and as a politician blessed with sound judgment born of years of experience within the Labor movement. It is a standard of ACT Senate representation of which the Australian Labor Party can be justly proud. It is a standard established by the first Labor Party senator for the ACT, Susan Ryan, and maintained by Bob McMullan.

Susan, Bob and I are very different people, but we are all united in our commitment to social justice and our concern for people. This is the duty and responsibility now handed me. I will pursue the principles and practice of equity and justice to the best of my ability in the hope that I can do my remarkable predecessors proud.

I would like to say a few words about former Senator Ryan and her historical contribution to, amongst many other things, the status of women in Australia, a contribution that had a direct impact upon me as a young woman seeking employment for the first time. I share with around 30 per cent of parliamentarians a higher education consisting not of tertiary qualifications but of life experience.

In September 1984, at 16 years of age, I found myself employed in an industry largely unexplored by women. No, I am not talking about the parliament; I am talking about the building and construction industry.

The Sex Discrimination Act had become law in August of that year and my experience is a tangible example of the positive difference significant legislation can make to the daily lives of ordinary Australians. This event set me on a path, albeit unexpected; a path that I have been honoured to follow. Hence, finding myself in this chamber presenting my first speech 12 years later, but still with a scaffolders ticket in my pocket, is a positive reflection on the accessibility of the democratic political processes which are fundamental to both the Labor Party and the Australian nation. May I say that in this reflection we see the presence and contribution of many women, including pioneers like Dorothy Tangney, Enid Lyons, Margaret Guilfoyle and Susan Ryan—all of whom have opened doors for other women. But it was the work of Susan Ryan that, for me, opened that first door.

BREAK.PARA: These days, however, it is not enough just to hold open these doors. By being here I gladly carry with me a responsibility, as do all women elected to this chamber and the other place, to strive for the removal of those doors altogether. And Labor started the process—so successfully in fact that our opponents have belatedly jumped on the bandwagon and renewed my certainty that one day there will be no trace of the barriers that once blocked the full and active participation in the political processes by more than half of the population.

The fact that someone like myself is here is the result of the selfless, dedicated and diligent work of many Labor women over the years. I would like to take this opportunity to thank my family, all of whom have supported me in everything I have ever undertaken—especially my partner George Wason. I came from an essentially non‐political upbringing, spending my early childhood in Quirindi, New South Wales, before moving to Canberra when I was six years old.

I particularly want to thank my Labor Party and union colleagues and my friends, all of whom have given me strength and confidence. I also thank them for sharing this occasion with me. My children Alexandra and Annabelle, whom I hope, with the pursuance of the family friendly environment up here on Capital Hill, will only be affected in positive ways by their mother's choice to enter federal parliament.

There are many others who have played a pivotal role in my life. One of those is Rod Driver who, against the best advice, took a risk and employed me as a union organiser in the building and construction industry. Thank you, Rod: your faith in me changed my life.

The ideals pursued by the union movement of equality in society and a fair go for all epitomise the Australian psyche. The sense of purpose that comes with improving the lot of others was something that I could not, and will not, let go. Unions, through their collective campaigns, have secured over a very long period of time many improvements for working people.

I have a saying that I would like to share. For a worker to refuse to belong to a union is not to exercise a democratic freedom; it is to accept benefits that others have worked for without contributing to the costs. Democracy flourishes only when freedom is accompanied by responsibility.

It is the achievements in occupational health and safety standards, hours of work, wage rates, superannuation, long service leave, family leave, and the vast array of other award provisions that union members have worked so hard for that have shaped Australian workplaces. These achievements have only been possible because of our sensible industrial relations legislation. I am talking about legislation that has taken nearly a century to evolve.

The Industrial Relations Act provides for both an equitable forum in which all industrial parties—employees and employers alike—can resolve their differences as well as an environment which recognises the right of working people to unite and use their collective strength to protect their family's standard of living. Even employer associations admit that Labor's industrial relations system does work well. The awards provide the benchmark for employment standards and they must be protected. The achievements of unions are embodied in the awards and to lose them, as is proposed by the coalition, would unravel a century of effort by working people.

Labor has and always will recognise this effort. Also, Labor has embodied a commonsense approach to the prevention of workplace illness and injury by way of legislation that involved all parties in the determination and implementation of minimum safety standards. The various state—and now federal—coalition governments have subsequently moved to systematically dismantle this tripartite approach to health and safety.

With 500 workplace deaths and thousands of injuries occurring each year I question their priorities. Surely the health and safety of all Australians must be first and foremost in the minds of all legislators. I would like to take this opportunity to put on the public record my support for the initiatives taken to put in place very strong gun control laws in Australia, and I express my deepest sympathy for the tragic events that have unfolded in Tasmania in recent times.

We, as Australians, can no longer take for granted the standard of living and conditions of employment that we have become used to. Working people will need to enlighten themselves very quickly as to the strategies and support available to them through the union movement in the face of what will be a systematic erosion of their rights.

It is an unfortunate thing that political awareness is often triggered as a result of a problem occurring, whether it be in one's personal or professional life, and it is therefore crucial that initiatives such as the civics educational program attract bipartisan support. This program aims to empower everyone, regardless of their age, ethnicity or class, with knowledge about the Australian political system.

I predict that many people will have their political awareness raised over the next few years. I have already seen the ranks of the Australian Labor Party swelling as a direct response to the uncaring, unfair and undemocratic industrial relations policy that this coalition government is espousing.

My own involvement in politics was something that emerged from my experience of working on building sites. Before that, I was like many other young people: pretty cynical about politics. This cynicism must be addressed by all of us. We can all assist in restoring public faith in the political processes by being true to our policies and to ourselves.

PARA.BREAK: This is a big ask, but I for one am determined to earn the respect of the people I represent by contributing to the fair and effective public debate of issues which directly affect the quality of lives of Australian families. The issues we, as senators, will discuss and decide are the very issues which will determine what sort of life my daughters, and indeed the next generation, will experience. My vision has been formed by the proud tradition of Labor principles expressed and refined over a century—a tradition which values actions above words and which, quite frankly, is offended by the attitude inherent in a profit first, people last ideology. It is Labor's ability to act decisively that distin guishes us from the other parties—our ability to put in place fair policies that go to the very heart of the just society.

BREAK.PARA: The achievements of Labor in the form of Medicare, the social security safety net, affordable and accessible child care, school retention rates, Aboriginal reconciliation, the accord, universal superannuation, the forest conservation reserve system, coast and land care, law reform, APEC and providing a vision for the Australian republic have all contributed to the shaping of our identity as a community.

The need for sustainable jobs is at the forefront of public concern and has seen Labor implement comprehensive strategies, such as Working Nation, as a means of addressing this basic right of employment. Labor puts job creation and job security at the top of our list of priorities. We saw this proud legacy being adopted by the coalition during the election campaign in its desperation to win government. Subsequently, we have seen the same legacy tossed out the window as the coalition settles into its real agenda.

It is this ideology which will alienate this government from the people. Dry economic rhetoric and conservative propaganda promoting the new individualism will not fool the electorate. It will only serve to remind voters of the high price they are being forced to pay under the coalition. People of my generation who are experiencing adult life under a coalition government for the first time will quickly appreciate, if they have not already, the crystal clear distinction between the major parties. The Australian Labor Party has learnt the hard way the importance of genuine communication with the electorate, and we will go back to the people because our Labor ideology is based on equity, not elitism.

Information and how it is communicated are major determinants of power in our society. Many people have little restriction on their ability to convey their views, but there are also many disadvantaged members of our community who, through circumstances beyond their control, find it very difficult to have their voice heard. Therefore, there is a need to ensure that all groups in our society have the public means and the opportunity to form their views without media bias and to be able to express them freely. The importance of public policy relating to the use and control of credible information sources and its increasingly complex delivery technologies cannot be underestimated if we are serious about equitable and affordable access.

By the year 2000 the information sector will be the world's second largest industry. Those nations that develop the infrastructure necessary for this industry to flourish are the nations that will prosper into the next millennium. Infrastructure is not just cable and microwave dishes; it is an education and training system which can increase people's skills in developing software and creating useful content. Already in Australia information and information related activities employ more than 40 per cent of the work force and generate 36 per cent of gross domestic product, and this can only improve.

High quality communications, widespread computer usage and literacy, and a willingness to use modern engineering technologies will be essential ingredients in our economic wellbeing. However, I am not yet convinced that we have sufficiently analysed and discussed the societal and community effects of this shift in our economic base. For example, although the need to take this technology to rural Australia is well recognised, have we explored the long‐term impact on the economies of country towns? The geography of Australia provides special challenges in terms of access to information infrastructure; challenges that can be met only in a policy framework with priorities of equal access, universal service and that which puts the needs of Australians—both suppliers and consumers—first. The best way of ensuring this is through public ownership.

We need only to look to Canberra, the nation's capital and my home, to see the rewards that come from investing in information technology and what it brings to a government administration. There is no doubt that this investment in technology has been a major contributor to the increases in efficiency achieved by the public sector, and to cut expenditure in this area would be short‐sighted and foolish.

Canberra bashing has long been a hobby for the coalition. Uncharacteristically, the government restricted its rhetoric during the election campaign and implied to the people of Canberra that public sector job losses would be restricted to 2,500 positions with no forced redundancies. With every passing day, however, the list of cuts grows longer. Now I believe that even the Real Estate Institute of Australia in the Australian Capital Territory is begging the ministers to curb their lust for job cuts. I know that many of my Senate colleagues understand as well as I do the kind of negative impact this will have on our community.

I have been inundated with letters and calls from people who are living in real fear of being declared `excess'. The impact upon themselves, their personal morale and their families is devastating. These are the people at the front line of the government's harsh, dry political prescriptions, but they are not the only ones that will be affected. The quality of service delivery for every Australian in need will be compromised.

SPEECH.PARA: But in addition to the right to govern, the coalition claim that they have a mandate to have their legislation enacted by the parliament, in spite of what the parliament may itself feel is right, simply because they won this handsome victory at the last election. That is the proposition that is put: that the people have spoken and, having spoken, that the coalition are entitled not only to form a government but to have passed all that legislation that touches upon the policies that they introduced at the last election. That is a proposition which I think is not correct because this concept of mandate is not a concept—

TALK.START.PARA: —We got five million votes; you got four million.

—Senator MacGibbon has made the interjection that I think shows up what needs to be talked about. Senator MacGibbon, who I heard speak before when he said some very wise things about the Defence Force, is very perceptive in putting forward the arguments that ought to be put forward. He said very graphically, `We got about five million votes; you got about four million votes. That is the end of the matter. That is the mandate.' What that gives you, Senator MacGibbon, through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, is this: the right to govern; the right to form the ministry; the right to select the person who will be Prime Minister, the political head of the administration—and you have done that—and the right to have the policies that you put forward be the policies that the administration follow in administering the country. There is no doubt about that.

SPEECH.PARA: But that is not the proposition you put. You are going a bit further than that. The proposition you put is this: that we, on this side of the chamber, should agree with whatever legislation you put forward that in some way touches upon the policies you put forward at the last election. Specifically what you talk about is Telstra. You say you made it clear, which you did, that as a government you were going to sell one‐third of Telstra—you were going to bring legislation down to do that.

Your proposition was that, since you have five million votes to our four million votes, we should pass that legislation. This is in spite of the fact that the parliament, as defined under the constitution, is so constituted in this place now that you are unable to do that unless this side of the Senate gives way to the proposition that it does not matter what the constitution says, what the conventions are or what the numbers on this side are, or what our conscience is, what our beliefs are and what we put forward in the election. All these do not matter. None of that is relevant where you have been elected by, you say, five million to four million votes. Your proposition is that we should pass your legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —What if the privatisation of Telstra is part of the budget bills?

—If the sale of Telstra is part of a budget bill and you are not able to keep government going without that sale, to take your proposition, then I think you are entitled to have sufficient money to keep government going. But that does not mean that you have the right in your budget bills to claim money for whatever you want. All that you have the right to do according to your budget is to get sufficient money to continue the usual functions of government. The sale of Telstra is not, may I say, necessary for you to continue the proper functions of government.

SPEECH.PARA: I also want to put this proposition: say you have a budget and the sale of Telstra, just for the sake of argument, was necessary for you to carry on the functions of government, but you had an alternative such as increasing taxation and we were willing to put through such bills, then you would have to take that alternative rather than the sale of Telstra.

We are talking now about the issue of mandates. There is a distinction to be drawn between mandates and conventions. It is a convention, for example, which we have to give way to that if you have a majority in the House of Representatives you form the government of this country. That is a convention which we could not possibly stand against.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want to know what Mr Howard said about it?

—Yes, I do want to know what Mr Howard said about it. I will come to that. It is a convention, too, that the Governor‐General, for example, takes the advice of the Prime Minister and of the properly constituted government of the country. It is a convention to which this country needs to adhere to run properly that the Governor‐General, on a matter which affects the government, should consult the government and the Prime Minister. Those are conventions. The danger of not adhering to those conventions was illustrated in 1975 when the Governor‐General did not consult the then Prime Minister on an issue that very much affected the government of the day. They are conventions but they are certainly different from a mandate. Indeed, the word `mandate' is not mentioned in the constitution but the concept of parliament is. It is mentioned in part I, section 1 of the constitution and it reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The legislative power of the Commonwealth shall be vested in a Federal Parliament, which will consist of the Queen, a Senate, and a House of Representatives, and which is here‐in after called "The Parliament," or "The Parliament of the Commonwealth."

If the government of the day cannot get its legislation through the parliament, it cannot overbear the express provisions of the constitution by saying, `Look, we should have the legislative power. The legislative power of the Commonwealth should not be in the parliament, it should be in our mandate.' That is a proposition that has been put forward again and again recently and it is a proposition that cannot stand, by the very express words of the constitution. A mandate cannot overcome a convention and it certainly cannot overcome a constitution.

Some people may say—and it is not only the government that says this; many commentators say it—that the parliament should ignore the express directions it is given, the express power that is given in the constitution, and should somehow pass the legislation that is put up by the other side simply because that legislation was much canvassed during the campaign. Clearly that cannot be done. The constitution clearly says it is not right to do that. We would be failing in our obligation under the constitution if we were to give way to legislation about which we had great doubts. If we think it ought to be opposed, it would be wrong to nevertheless let it through because there was this concept of mandate. Perhaps this concept of mandate is best set out in Odgers' Australian Senate Practice.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is also in Mr Howard's words, actually.

—I will come to Mr Howard's words, thank you, Senator Bolkus. I will just use the words of Odgers. I see that the Deputy Clerk, Anne Lynch, is present, a great parliamentarian, and also Mr Cleaver Elliott. They certainly know this passage from Odgers. It reads:

BREAK.PARA: Armed as it is by the Constitution with extensive powers, it is in the judgment of the Senate of the day to decide whether or not to insist on any of its legislative amendments disagreed to by the House of Representatives, or in certain cases to refuse to pass a bill at all. As such power should be used circumspectly and wisely, factors which the Senate may take into account in reaching such decisions include:

(1) A recognition of the fact that the House of Representatives represents in its entirety the most recent choice of the people whereas, because of the system of rotation of senators and except in the case of simultaneous dissolution of the two Houses, one‐half of the Senate reflects an earlier poll.
(2) The principle that in a bicameral parliament one house shall be a check upon the power of the other.

(3) Whether the matter in dispute is a question of principle for which the government may claim a mandate or electoral approval; if so, the Senate may yield. The Senate is unlikely to resist legislation in respect of which a government can truly claim explicit electoral endorsement, but the test is always likely to be the public interest.

What is said there, Senator O'Chee, and I have great respect for your constitutional knowledge, is this: a mandate is certainly a factor that you have to take into account as a parliament, that we have to take into account as a Senate, but it is not the determining factor. It is one of the factors and, in any event, is always overridden by what the Senate would regard as the public interest.

People such as Senator Kernot, who has been much criticised in here, has said that again and again. It is enshrined in the words of Mr Odgers, a very distinguished clerk and the teacher of many distinguished clerks, deputy clerks and assistant clerks in this place. So the arguments on mandate put forward in this chamber, in the other chamber and generally in the public, ought to be seen in that light.

Interestingly, it has often been said that, because half the Senate were elected this year and all the House of Representatives were elected this year, those people elected have a greater right as legislators than others here who were elected in 1993. If you are going into the generational distinction then you have to ask yourself: if it is generation that determines whether legislation goes through, then what do we do about a bill like the one covering the sale of Telstra? If Telstra is sold, it is sold forever.

Say future generations of legislators come into this place with a mandate from people who, if they had had the opportunity, would have preserved Telstra. What will they do once it is gone? On this argument about generational prerogatives, would it not then be unjust that the present generation of politicians determine the decision area of future politicians?

The sale of Telstra cannot be argued on the basis of a mandate given in the last election, because the sale of Telstra will affect not only this generation of parliamentarians but also future generations of Australians and people who will want to then use it. The only proper way to analyse this in the end is to ask what the parliament wants to do. As the constitution says, the parliament consists of the House of Representatives, the Senate and the Queen.

Overriding a mandate, indeed, overriding the parliament itself, is the concept of the rule of law. This is something we ought to think about. A learned judge in the last century in Victoria, Mr Justice Molesworth, in a case called Dill v. Murphy, or Murphy v. Dill—I forget now which name comes first—talked about parliament being `despotic'. For example, take the situation in Victoria now. I think Mr Justice Brooking referred to this in a case that he was deciding where in that state there was a question as to whether or not the parliament was a despot. I do not say that in the sense that it was evil but that it was despotic.

If you have anybody, whether elected or not, who has despotic powers, then there is certainly the opportunity for injustice, the opportunity to exercise arbitrary power. I think one of the annual reports of the Supreme Court of Victoria uses the phrase, `the risk of corruption' if you have an uncontrolled despotic power.

The way to get over this problem and have some sort of control over the exercise of power is the concept of the rule of law. That concept has been exercised more in the federal field than in the state field. In the federal field, the High Court has applied this concept of saying there is an overarching principle above the principle that parliament can do whatever it legislates to do. The cases of free speech at a political level give examples of that proposition at a federal level.

Under the concept of the rule of law, everybody is treated equally and everybody has the opportunity to approach the courts of law and have access to the fundamentals of life in food, shelter, warmth and what have you. Lots of those concepts are relevant when talking about Telstra, which seems to have been spoken about a lot today and previously. One of the great issues of debate on the sale of Telstra concerns the universal service that is now given to people around Australia. Some people get the service at a lot less than the real cost and other people pay more but, as has been said by both Senator Mackay and Senator Lundy, the principle operates that everybody in Australia is part of the community and the concept comes to the fore whereby some people give up something that they might otherwise be entitled to for the good of others who are more entitled to those fundamentals provided by this rule of law.

Another example of where the rule of law applies—and this is going to be a matter of great debate in this chamber over the next few months—is in relation to the issue of industrial relations. The industrial relations argument will be based on the concepts of society and what they mean. Are we going to embrace the principle of contracts between two people or between one group and another on the basis that people can work out what they want and then that will be enshrined in the contract and that is the end of the matter, or are we going to embrace the principle that there is a difference in strength in the bargaining positions of people and that there is great danger where there is this difference that one person will be overborne by another.

Going right back to the statute of labourers, which was made 600‐odd years ago, there was this concept that an agreement was the be all and end all. Since that time, this concept has led to great injustices. One of the great institutions to overcome that injustice is the union movement.

It is interesting to read documents these days that used to be considered quite conservative. Because of the way the world has changed and because of the move towards individualism and away from community standards these documents are beginning to look almost revolutionary. As a school boy many years ago—and Senator Jacinta Collins may well remember these documents—

TALK.START.PARA: —When you were a school boy?

—Senator Woods surely would have read Rerum Novarum by Pope Leo XIII. Were you taught that at school, Senator Woods? If you were not, I am going to ensure that you have a copy of it. I am sure the Deputy Clerk knows about Rerum Novarum and, 40 years later, the letter by Pius XI, Quadragesimo Anno —the 40th year. I see that the Deputy Clerk is nodding to acknowledge that.

BREAK.PARA: If you look at those things you will see the contrast between these two great concepts of what society and what people are all about. I am not saying for one minute that Senator Woods is not the most sincere person and a great medical doctor: I am saying that the concepts he has, because he is one of those who adheres very much to individualism, can lead to quite destructive legislation. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

DEBATE.TITLE: HAZARDOUS WASTE (REGULATION OF EXPORTS AND IMPORTS) AMENDMENT BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.
The bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The committee is considering the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Bill 1996. When the committee was last considering the bill, it had dealt with the first item on the list of amendments circulated by Senator Chamarette. The question is that the bill stand as printed.
—I move:

BREAK.PARA: 2. Schedule 1, item 27, page 14 (line 3), omit "practicable steps", substitute "necessary steps".

The reason for this amendment is that the word `practicable' can be considered as enabling unspecified commercial considerations relating to profitability to dictate and take precedence over sound environmental practice. `Practicable' is a word that implicitly leaves up to an incumbent what is practicable and what is not. That is the reason why I believe the definition of `environmentally sound management' must be the taking of all necessary steps to ensure safe management of wastes.
