TALK.START.PARA: —As this is the first occasion that I have had to speak since the first speeches of Senator Mackay and Senator Lundy, let me congratulate them on their first performances in this chamber. However, I could not help but note in both those speeches—and indeed detect within the Australian Labor Party's general program in recent times—that the Labor Party is absolutely determined to continue the campaign of untruths about our policy to sell one‐third of Telstra.

SPEECH.PARA: It is vitally important that we bring to the attention of the public the duplicity of Labor's campaign. Labor has been asking the people to believe them about Telstra. But, of course, all throughout the last election campaign the Australian Labor Party quite deceitfully circulated within electorates around Australia mock telephone bills, using—unlawfully, I would suggest—the Telstra logo and symbol. More importantly, there was the unauthorised use of the ACN number which has been allocated to Telstra Corporation Ltd. Indeed, the mock bills were circulated to such an extent and provided such a degree of concern within the community that Telstra itself found it necessary to issue media releases dissociating itself from this dishonest campaign.

As you would be aware, Mr Acting Deputy President, within Tasmania, especially within the electorate of Lyons, this was used to an art form by the Australian Labor Party. I believe that this quite dishonest campaign allowed the sitting Labor member to win that seat. Telstra, three days before the election, put out a media release entitled `Mock bills concern Telstra.' It said:
Telstra Corporation Limited today repeated its concern about imitation Telstra bills being circulated as election campaign material.
It goes on to say:
We are concerned that comments from customers indicate many believe use of or a representation of Telstra's logo and/or wordmark indicate Telstra endorsement or approval of election material.

That was clearly within the minds of the Australian Labor Party operatives, people such as the then state secretary of the Labor Party in Tasmania, Sue Mackay, in their campaign to try to let the electorate believe that these brochures were in fact authorised by Telstra when clearly they were not so authorised. They caused confusion within the electorate and I believe unwittingly allowed the Labor member for Lyons to retain his seat. However, the people of Tasmania will be continually reminded of the dishonesty of the Labor Party campaign concerning Telstra and their allegations which were, quite astoundingly, repeated in one of the first speeches that we heard this evening.

The allegation about network charges, quite clearly, is false. There is no basis for it. There is no foundation for that assertion in any shape or form. In fact, during the election campaign, I publicly challenged the Labor Party to come out with their documentation in support of the various prices that they were alleging would be incurred by way of a network charge. Of course, not a single Labor person responded to that challenge. The dishonesty of the campaign concerning Telstra is highlighted in view of the fact that the Labor Party itself ran these sorts of campaigns against the privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank, the Federal Airports Corporation and Qantas—and the list goes on.

What did the Labor Party's former leader have to say about Telstra when asked on ABC's Lateline in 1994 whether it mattered if Telstra was publicly or privately owned. The then Prime Minister said, `Of its essence, it mattered nothing.' Former powerbroker, Graham Richardson, who in fact allowed Paul Keating to become Prime Minister, at pages 305 and 306 of his book Whatever it takes writes about the proposal concerning Telecom. He said:
This wimpish proposal did not satisfy Paul Keating, who wanted to go much further and sell off Telecom into the bargain.

It has always been part of Paul Keating's agenda—exactly the same as the GST. And now, the federal secretary of the Australian Labor Party all of a sudden is starting to say, `Look, let's think about this. A GST might be a good idea.' All of a sudden, the Labor Party are embracing this policy; similarly, I suggest, with Telstra.

It was Paul Keating's idea to sell off Telstra, the whole lot of it. He went to an election campaign saying, `Oh, no, we can't sell any of it.' I am sure within a few years Labor will do the full circle yet again and say, `How about selling it off?' The Labor Party campaign and, might I add, the Australian Democrats' campaign in relation to Telstra, is quite disingenuous. Today, we were submitted to a ridiculous matter, allegedly of public importance, criticising us for not strictly abiding by every actual policy initiative with which we had gone to the election. I would have thought there was no clearer policy than our policy on Telstra. If the Labor Party and the Democrats, who supported the Labor Party, clearly want us to follow every single election issue that we went to the people with, they would support us on Telstra.

But they do not want to. Why not? They want us to stick to all our election promises, but they do not want us to stick to them if it suits them. The duplicity of the Labor Party and indeed the Australian Democrats is further shown in relation to their stance on industrial relations. We campaigned very effectively on the unfair dismissal law. The Labor Party and the Australian Democrats went to the people opposing us on that. Now, after the election, the Labor Party and the Democrats are seriously considering their position. They are saying, `We may well go along with the Liberal Party on this.' They themselves will be breaking the promises they made to the Australian people.

Indeed, former senator Bob McMullan is now on record as saying, the chances are, if Labor ever got re-elected, they would never re‐enter into an accord with the trade union movement. The Labor Party and the Democrats have to be made to be honest and accountable in relation to their criticism of us on policy issues and also when they look at themselves on policy issues.

BREAK.PARA: The situation is very clear. The Liberal‐National Party coalition received on overwhelming mandate in relation to the part‐privatisation of Telstra. We have a mandate for it. For the Labor Party and the Democrats to combine, yet again, to oppose us on this issue would in effect mean that they will not allow us to remain truthful to the election policies that we went to the people with. I look forward to the Labor Party and the Australian Democrats doing a U-turn on Telstra in the same way that they have done on unfair dismissals.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Deaths at Port ArthurCondolences: Mr Rob Riley

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarrette, Sen Christabel

TALK.START.PARA: —The tragedy which occurred last week in Port Arthur has loomed large in every Australian's heart and mind. I too wish to express my deepest sorrow to the families and all the people who were associated with that tragedy in Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: But something else happened at the time we were all still reeling from the events in Tasmania that moved me in an intensely personal way. I speak of the death of Rob Riley. I would take the opportunity here to just speak very briefly of this man and his death, news of which came on Wednesday, 1 May. This afternoon we were able to pass a formal motion of condolence to Rob Riley's family and friends and express our support.

It is highly appropriate that the Senate should commemorate the tragedy of the loss of yet another young Aboriginal person—a loss not only to his own people but to everyone who knew him. The tragedy of that loss can be seen as an expression of the sadness and shame of the early death of so many leaders among Aboriginal people which comes as a result of over 200 years of our failure to really recognise the rights of indigenous people and what has been done to them during the time of colonisation. May we look to the day when Aboriginal people can expect to live to a ripe old age in a society which accepts and honours them and shares the wisdom of their ancient culture.

I express my condolences to Rob's family, to all his friends and people in Western Australia in particular who mourn his loss. Rob Riley, a former chairman of the National Aboriginal Council, was a wonderful expression of the call for social justice and the cry for justice for his people. It was very fitting that on Saturday the Canberra Aboriginal Church called the nation to prayer for justice by organising a prayer vigil just outside Parliament House. I believe that it is symbolic events of this kind that will transform the face of Australian society into looking to addressing the kinds of underlying causes of not only the tragedy in Tasmania but also the tragedy that many Aboriginal people have suffered.

A statement and invitation was issued by Flo Grant, Secretary of the Canberra Aboriginal Church, in association with the Wiradjuri Christian Development Ministries and Elder of the Wiradjuri Council of Elders. It states:

This Rally was put into progress two weeks ago. We now extend our sympathies to the people of Tasmania and express how very sorry we feel about the dreadful tragedy of last Sunday. We will be adding the family and friends of those who lost their lives, were injured and traumatised by this dreadful time to the prayer points of the Prayer for Justice rally on Saturday.
I am sure I speak for all Aboriginal people as well as the churches.
In that rally for justice there was a most powerful statement read out which was called The Power of the Gun. In a few moments I will seek leave to have that statement incorporated in Hansard .

I have just a few more words about the reason for the calling of that rally, because I believe it is something that Rob Riley lived for and would have liked to see continue and be advanced. Despite the sorrow people feel for his death, I am sure that he would want us to remember the wonderful things he did and to be able to work for that change within our society. I would like to keep working for that in response to the sorrow of the loss of his life.

In the pray for justice rally, some very pertinent statements were made in relation to what Aboriginal people have been feeling in the last few weeks about the kinds of comments that have been generated in the political arena. The statement of the call to prayer for justice states:

BREAK.PARA: The Aboriginal people of this land continue to be at the mercy of politicians who only see us as `the Aboriginal problem' and began throwing money to infrastructures of their making from 1967 to address this problem. They continually promote us as a drain on the national economy—with no recognition of our dispossession of this great continent and their responsibility as the dispossessors.
To continue quoting from that statement:

The newly elected government is also continuing to talk reconciliation whilst Aboriginal people hold grave concern about the effects of what we see as an attack on all Aboriginal people by the government as it scrutinises the integrity of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) without intimation or consultation. This action has Aboriginal people divided and talk back radio and other media programs tell us the opinions of the wider Australian society regarding Aboriginal people and issues such as Native Title, land rights and compensation for Aboriginal dispossession. The arrogant attitude portrayed is far from progressing toward reconciliation.
As a response to those concerns, people were called together to work in a positive way for change, requesting consideration and consultation.
I would like to conclude my remarks by reading a portion of the Aboriginal tribute to the deaths in Tasmania and seek leave to incorporate the balance. The tribute reads:

Aboriginal Australia, along with every Australian, is shocked and distressed by the cruel and heartless massacre of defenceless men, women and children at Port Arthur, Tasmania. Sunday, April 28th will always be remembered as a tragic day in our history. Thank God for those who survived the gunman! For sure, he meant to kill them all.

Our prayers and condolences are with all who experienced the violence and will suffer the trauma for the rest of their lives. Aboriginal people know only too well the trauma of having suffered violence at the hands of others. The Myall Creek and Murdering Island massacres are examples among many across the country where whole families, indeed complete tribes, were entirely wiped out.

Mr Howard and his government are to be encouraged and assisted in every way to secure better and more uniform gun control laws—those who use the gun to kill in vengeance or for sport ought to be despised by all right minded men. But gun control is not the complete answer, Mr Howard! As you well know, governments must deal truthfully and wisely with the injustices and inequities still far too prevalent throughout our country causing many to become frustrated and angry and the irrational few to resort to the violence seen in Melbourne, Sydney and now Hobart.
I seek leave to incorporate the remaining paragraphs of this statement in Hansard . I express my appreciation of the people who met at the rally.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

Australia will never know deliverance, nor real reconciliation, until we sincerely face the fact that this continent was taken by: "The power of the gun", which commenced on the 26th January 1788. Others came in peace and left peacefully, but the British came intent on annexing an entire continent. We as a Nation will never be rid of the blame, or the shame, until we face the truth of the past 208 years and deliver real justice to the surviving remnants of those first invaded Australians.

Justice for all Australians is tied unavoidably to justice for Aboriginal Australians. The fact that Aboriginal people have not resorted to violence upon others in their struggle for justice, as in other parts of the world, is a tribute to their patient and peaceful nature. They would sooner inflict violence upon themselves, eg. Aboriginal deaths in custody and a growing number of suicides are of great concern to us all.
The God to whom we rightly turn for comfort in times of sorrow is the same God who demands that all men everywhere deal justly with each other.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on the adjournment debate this evening to refer to a matter concerning the Prime Minister's code of conduct for ministers. I was grossly misrepresented by the Prime Minister in the House of Representatives today. I hope that the Prime Minister's gross misrepresentation of what I said was not deliberate. I will take the trouble to fax to the Prime Minister the Hansard of my remarks tonight and the transcript of last night's ABC PM program. These two documents will make it abundantly clear to the Prime Minister just how badly he misrepresented me.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn firstly to the comments that the Prime Minister made concerning Senator Herron. In a statement he made in the House of Representatives today he appeared to clarify the position that I have been taking on this issue. The Prime Minister said this:

BREAK.PARA: Senator Herron obviously has some patients who are in his care. I think it is only plain commonsense that he be allowed to see some of those through. The idea that you suddenly drop a patient on whom you have operated the previous week because you have become a minister is ridiculous. Anybody who argues that is even more ridiculous. That is the first part of the question I have answered.

As you know, Mr Acting Deputy President—you were here—not only did I not suggest anything so absurd, but it was explicit in the question I put to Senator Herron that I was not suggesting that. Hansard will indicate that.

However, as we all know, that is not what Senator Herron was seeking to do. He made it clear here in the parliament and on television interviews that he wanted to continue—for some years into the future, presumably—a continuous practice in surgery on new patients. It was a situation that he described as being `weekend hobby surgery'. They were Senator Herron's words, not mine.
I am pleased to see that the Prime Minister stated explicitly in the House of Representatives today that he has ruled that out. Having misquoted what I said, the Prime Minister goes on to say:
The second part is that there is no question at all of Senator Herron continuing a medical practice—and I have made that perfectly clear to him. He will be a full‐time minister.

Presumably, Mr Acting Deputy President, the Prime Minister must have made that clear to Senator Herron some time between question time in the House of Representatives yesterday and now. Clearly Senator Herron had not received that message yesterday and he was still arguing the case forcefully in the Senate that the position he would put to the Prime Minister at the end of this month would be that he could be a part‐time Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs and a `weekend hobby surgeon'.

The Prime Minister now has to be responsible for some of the extraordinary assertions that Senator Herron cast at me across this chamber. In response to the questions that I asked about ministerial accountability, Senator Herron claimed that the opposition was attempting to force him to choose between representing the interests of Aboriginal Australians and the interests of his surgical patients. He went so far as to suggest that I would be putting his surgery support staff out of work if I forced him to make the decision to give up surgery. Well, as it happens, the Prime Minister has made it abundantly clear that that was a nonsensical assertion by Senator Herron.

It was the Prime Minister who tabled this code of conduct for ministers in both the House of Representatives and the Senate. I might add that this code of conduct goes all the way down the line to include parliamentary secretaries as well as ministers. I will have something to say about the absurdity of that at a later stage. It is not parliamentary secretaries who argue submissions in cabinet and therefore put themselves in direct conflict with interest situations. It is ministers who do that. Nevertheless, this was the code of conduct that Mr Howard produced with a great flourish. He said it was the first time that this had ever been done.
I turn now to the misrepresentation by Mr Howard in respect of Mr John Anderson. Once again I quote from the Hansard where the Prime Minister said:

Let me come to the allegations, if you can dignify them with such a description, that have been made by Senator Collins about the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Apparently, in some way, it is wrong to be a primary producer and a minister. That is the proposition implicit in what Senator Collins said.
Of course, I said nothing so absurd.

In what I said on the ABC PM program last night and here in parliament, I was not suggesting that because he was a primary producer John Anderson should not be a cabinet minister. What I said was that, as minister for primary industry, he clearly was in breach—and remains in breach—of the code issued by the Prime Minister. As Minister for Social Security he would not be in breach of it; as minister for health he would not be in breach of it; as Minister for Resources he would not be in breach of it. But as minister for primary industry he is.

I have with me a copy of the Cabinet handbook that I operated under for the whole time I was a minister. This is a document produced by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, which is updated from time to time. This document binds, properly, all ministers to a code of behaviour. The bottom line of this code is that being a federal minister is a full‐time job and you cannot even appear to have a conflict of interest between your own affairs and your responsibilities as a minister.

A reference to the Cabinet handbook indicates only too clearly that much of the code tabled in parliament last week has been lifted directly from the Cabinet handbook. The relevant section of the code of the Prime Minister, which is copied from the Cabinet handbook, which John Anderson is still in breach of, is contained on page 7. The reason I make this point is that both the Prime Minister and John Anderson on Countrywide today have attempted to wriggle out of this by saying, `Oh, there's an exception for the family farm.'

Well, there is, Mr Acting Deputy President, but I suggest that they deliberately left out the second half of that paragraph which means there is an exemption for the family farm only if you are not the minister for primary industry. Again, this applies to all ministers except the minister for primary industry. A paragraph on page 10 of `A guide on key elements of ministerial responsibility' says:

Ministers are required to resign directorships in public companies and may retain directorships in private companies only if any such company operates, for example, a family farm, business or portfolio of investments—
It goes on to say this:
. . . and retention of the directorship is not likely to conflict with the minister's public duty—
If you are in any doubt about it, the next paragraph is even more explicit. It says:
Ministers are required to divest themselves of all shares and similar interests in any company or business involved in the area of their portfolio responsibilities.
I do not know that there is any ambiguity whatsoever attached to that paragraph. I might add that those sections are taken straight from `A guide on key elements of ministerial responsibility'.
There is a further requirement on ministers in the Cabinet handbook which is an entirely appropriate one. That is:

Apart from these formal declarations, Ministers at meetings of the Ministry, Cabinet and committees must declare any private interests, pecuniary or non‐pecuniary, held by themselves or members of their immediate families in matters under discussion, where those interests conflict or might conflict with their public duty as Ministers.
It goes on to say, and this is important and proper:
Ministers should adopt a broad interpretation of the requirement that they take into account the interests of family members and all interests of their own—

That is correct. It should not be a narrow interpretation. If there is even a broad chance that a submission conflicts with a minister's own pecuniary interests, then he has to declare it and absent himself, as we did, from debate or discussion on it.

From my own recent experience as primary industries minister, I know—and I have said this in here—that I took into cabinet many submissions that were vitally important to primary producers in Australia which would have clearly had me in breach of the Cabinet handbook had I been in the position of the current minister for primary industry. I am pleased to say that John Anderson said today on Countrywide that he will declare this interest and he will refrain from debate in cabinet, and even from voting, if the matter affects his interests as a beef and grain producer.
What that suggests—and, indeed, it is explicitly clear—is that John Anderson, by

definition, is going to be a less than effective Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. There is nobody that can carry a debate in cabinet better than you can yourself. In fact, you get very nervous if someone else is doing it for you. On at least half of the major submissions that John Anderson will take into cabinet on behalf of primary producers in Australia he will be precluded from carrying that debate himself in cabinet, not only by the Prime Minister's code of conduct but by the Cabinet handbook , which was our bible for our whole 13 years in government.
